tgt_text.3037: But, if it is agreeable to the company, continue the discussion, and ask any question you please.
tgt_text.3038: Socr. Hear then, Gorgias, what I wonder at in what you said.
tgt_text.3039: For, perhaps, you spoke correctly, and I did not rightly apprehend you.
tgt_text.3040: You say that you can make any one a rheto­ rician, who is willing to be instructed by you ?
tgt_text.3044: So that he can speak persuasively on any subject to the multitude, not teaching, but persuading?
tgt_text.3048: You said too, that a rhetorician is able to speak more persuasively than a physician, on the subject of health.
tgt_text.3050: I did say so, at least to a multitude.
tgt_text.3052: Does not, then, this expression " to a multitude " mean to the ignorant ?
tgt_text.3053: for, surely, among the well-informed he will not be better able to persuade than the physician.
tgt_text.3057: If then he shall be better able to persuade than the physician, he is better able to persuade than one who possesses knowledge ?
tgt_text.3061: Although he is not a physician ?
tgt_text.3066: But he who is not a physician must, surely, be un­ skilled in those things in which a physician is skilled.
tgt_text.3069: He, therefore, who is ignorant will be more capable than one who possesses knowledge of persuading the ignorant, since a rhetorician is better able to persuade than a physician.
tgt_text.3070: Is this the result, or something else?
tgt_text.3072: That is the result in this instance.
tgt_text.3074: The case therefore is the same as concerns a rhetori­ cian and rhetoric with respect to all other arts :
tgt_text.3075: I mean, there is no need for it to know the subjects themselves, how they are circumstanced, but only to discover some means of persuasion, so as to appear to the ignorant to know more than those who possess knowledge.
tgt_text.3077: Is it not a great advantage, Socrates, without having other arts, but this one only, to be in no respect inferior to artificers ?
tgt_text.3080: Whether from this being the case, a rhetorician is inferior, or not inferior to others, we will presently consider, if our argument requires it.
tgt_text.3081: But first let us consider this:
tgt_text.3082: Whether a rhetorician is in the same condition with reference to the just and the unjust, the base and the honourable, the good and the evil, as he is with reference to health, and other things with which other arts are concerned;
tgt_text.3083: I mean, that he does not know them, what is good, or what is evil, what is honourable or what is base, what is just, or what is unjust, but is able to devise some means of persuasion respecting them, so that, though he is ignorant, he appears to the ignorant to know more than one who possesses knowledge;
tgt_text.3084: or is it neces­ sary that he should know these, and is it requisite that he who is about to learn rhetoric should have acquired these things before he comes to you;
tgt_text.3085: if not, will you, who are a teacher of rhetoric, teach him who conies to you none of these things (for it is not your province), but make him appear to the multitude to know these things, though he does not know them, and to seem to be a good man when he is not so ?
tgt_text.3086: or shall you be unable to teach him rhetoric at all, unless he knows beforehand the truth respecting these things?
tgt_text.3087: What is the case in this respect, Gorgias?
tgt_text.3088: And, by Jupiter, as you just now promised, unfold the whole power of rhetoric.
tgt_text.3090: I think, Socrates, that any one, if he did not know, would learn these things from me.
tgt_text.3093: If then you make any one a rhetorician, it is necessary that he should know what is just and unjust, either before, or afterwards from your instructions.
tgt_text.3098: Is he who has learnt carpentering, a carpenter, or not?
tgt_text.3102: And is not he who has learnt music, a musician ?
tgt_text.3106: And he who has learnt medicine, a physician ?
tgt_text.3107: And so, in the same way, with regard to other things, is not he who has learnt any particular art such a person as each science respectively makes its proficient ?
tgt_text.3111: By the same reason, then, does it not follow, that he who has learnt just things is just ?
tgt_text.3115: And he who is just surely performs just actions.
tgt_text.3118: Is it not, therefore, necessary' that the just man should wish to do just actions ?
tgt_text.3122: The just man, therefore, will never wish to act un­ justly.
tgt_text.3126: And it follows from the argument that the rhetori­ cian should be just ?
tgt_text.3130: A rhetorician, therefore, will never wish to act un­ justly ?
tgt_text.3134: Do you remember that you said a little before that we ought not to accuse the trainers of youth, nor expel them from cities, if a pugilist does not make a good use of the pugilistic art, and acts unjustly ?
tgt_text.3135: And so, likewise, if a rhe­ torician make an unjust use of rhetoric, that we should not accuse the teacher, nor expel him from the city, but the per­ son who acts unjustly, and does not make a proper use of rhe­ toric ?
tgt_text.3136: Were these things said, or not ?
tgt_text.3140: But now this very same rhetorician appears incapable of ever acting unjustly.
tgt_text.3145: And it was said, Gorgias, at the commencement of our discussion, that rhetoric is conversant with words, not those respecting the even and the odd, but those respecting the just and the unjust.
tgt_text.3148: When, therefore, you spoke thus, I supposed that rhe­ toric could never be an unjust thing, since it always discourses concerning justice.
tgt_text.3149: But when you said shortly afterwards that a rhetorician might use rhetoric unjustly, then, wondering, and thinking that the two statements did not accord, I made that remark, that if you should think it a gain to be confuted, as I do, it was worth while to continue the discussion, but if not, to give it up.
tgt_text.3150: Afterwards, however, when we were in­ vestigating the matter, you see yourself that it is again allowed to be impossible for a rhetorician to make an unjust use of rhetoric, and to be willing to act unjustly.
tgt_text.3151: How the case really stands, by the do-, Gorgias, requires no little discussion to examine it thoroughly.
tgt_text.3154: Have you really such an opinion of rhetoric as you now say ?
tgt_text.3155: or do you not think that Gorgias was ashamed not to acknowledge that the rheto­ rician knows what is just, beautiful, and good, and that, if any one should come to him ignorant of these things, he himself would teach them ?
tgt_text.3156: Then perhaps from this admission some inconsistency in his arguments followed ;
tgt_text.3157: the very thing which you love, yourself leading the way to such questions.
tgt_text.3158: For who do you think will deny that he knows what is just, and can teach it to others ?
tgt_text.3159: To lead the discussion to such matters is a piece of great rusticity.
tgt_text.3162: we get ourselves friends and sons, for this express purpose, that when we, through being advanced in years, fall into error, you that are younger, being with us, may correct our life both in deeds and words.
tgt_text.3163: If, then, Gorgias and I have fallen into any error in our argu­ ments, do you who are present correct us:
tgt_text.3165: And I wish that if any of the things that have been granted appear to you to have been improperly granted, you would retract whatever you please, only I beg you beware of one thing.
tgt_text.3170: That you would restrain that prolixity of speech which at first you attempted to employ.
tgt_text.3173: shall I not be allowed to speak as much as I please ?
tgt_text.3175: You would indeed be very badly treated, my excel­ lent friend, if, having come to Athens, where of all Greece there is the greatest liberty of speech, you alone should here be de­ prived of this liberty.
tgt_text.3177: if you speak in a prolix manner, and will not answer a question put to you, should not I be badly treated, if I am not allowed to go away and not listen to you ?
tgt_text.3178: But if you feel any interest in the dis­ cussion that has taken place, and wish to correct it, as I just now said, retract whatever you please, and questioning and being questioned in turn, as Gorgias and I did, confute and be confuted.
tgt_text.3179: For you profess, surely, to know the same things as Gorgias;
tgt_text.3184: Will not you, then, also bid any one ask you what question he pleases, as knowing how to answer him.
tgt_text.3187: Then do whichever of these you please, ask or answer.
tgt_text.3190: and do you answer me, Socrates.
tgt_text.3191: Since Gorgias appears to you to be in doubt respecting rheto­ ric, what do you say it is ?
tgt_text.3193: Do you ask me what kind of art I say it is ?
tgt_text.3197: To tell you the truth, Polus, it does not appear to me to be an art at all.
tgt_text.3199: What, then, does rhetoric appear to you to be ?
tgt_text.3201: A thing which you say produced art, in the treatise which I lately read.
tgt_text.3203: What do you say this is ?
tgt_text.3206: Does rhetoric, then, appear to you to be skill ?
tgt_text.3208: To me it does, unless you say otherwise.
tgt_text.3210: Of what is it the skill ?
tgt_text.3212: Of procuring a certain gratification and pleasure.
tgt_text.3214: Does not rhetoric, then, appear to you to be a beauti­ ful thing, since it is able to gratify mankind ?
tgt_text.3217: Have you already heard from me what I say it is, that you afterwards ask me, if it does not appear to me to be beautiful ?
tgt_text.3219: Did I not hear you say that it is a certain skill ?
tgt_text.3220: Socr. Since, then, you prize giving pleasure, are you willing to give me a little pleasure ?
tgt_text.3222: Ask me, then, what kind of art cookery appears to me to be.
tgt_text.3225: what kind of an art is cookery ?
tgt_text.3231: I say, then, it is a certain skill.
tgt_text.3236: I say, of procuring gratification and pleasure, Polus.
tgt_text.3238: Are cookery and rhetoric the same thing ?
tgt_text.3240: By no means, but a part of the same study.
tgt_text.3242: Of what study are you speaking ?
tgt_text.3244: I fear it would be too rude to speak the truth, for I hesitate to speak on account of Gorgias, lest he should think that I ridicule his profession.
tgt_text.3245: But I know not whether this is the rhetoric which Gorgias studies :
tgt_text.3246: for it was not at all clear from our late discussion what his opinion is.
tgt_text.3247: But what I call rhetoric is a part of a certain thing which does not rank among things beautiful.
tgt_text.3250: say, without fear of offend­ ing me.
tgt_text.3252: It appears to me, then, Gorgias, to be a certain study, that does not belong to art, but to a soul that is sagacious and manly, and naturally powerful in its intercourse with men.
tgt_text.3253: The sum of it I call flattery.
tgt_text.3254: 42. Of this study there appears to me to be many other divisions, and one of them is that of cookery;
tgt_text.3255: which, indeed, appears to be an art, but, as I main­ tain, is not an art, but skill and practice.
tgt_text.3256: I also call rhetoric a division of this, and personal decoration, and sophistry, these four divisions relating to four particulars.
tgt_text.3257: If, therefore, Polus wishes to enquire, let him enquire, for he has not yet heard what division of flattery I assert rhetoric to be :
tgt_text.3258: but he did not observe that I had not yet finished my answer, nevertheless he asks me, if I do not think that it is beautiful.
tgt_text.3259: But I shall not answer him, whether I think rhetoric is beautiful or base, till I have first answered what it is.
tgt_text.3260: For that would not be right, Polus.
tgt_text.3261: If then you wish to enquire, ask me what division of flattery I assert rhetoric to be.
tgt_text.3263: I ask, then, and do you answer, what division it is.
tgt_text.3265: Will you understand me when I answer ?
tgt_text.3266: For rhetoric, in my opinion, is a semblance of a division of the political art.
tgt_text.3269: Do you say that it is beautiful, or base ?
tgt_text.3272: for I call evil things base :
tgt_text.3273: since I must answer you, as now knowing what I mean.
tgt_text.3275: By Jupiter, Socrates, but I do not myself under­ stand what you mean.
tgt_text.3278: for I have not yet spoken clearly.
tgt_text.3279: But Polus here is young and hasty.
tgt_text.3282: and tell me in what way you say that rhetoric is a semblance of a division of the political art.
tgt_text.3284: I will endeavour to tell you what rhetoric appears to me to be.
tgt_text.3285: And if it is not such as I describe it, Polus here will confute me.
tgt_text.3286: Do you not call body something, and soul something ?
tgt_text.3288: Do you not, then, think that there is a certain good habit of each of these ?
tgt_text.3293: an apparent good habit, which is not really so ?
tgt_text.3294: for instance, to explain my meaning, many appear to have a good constitution of body, whom no one but a phy­ sician, and a teacher in gymnastics, could easily perceive not to have a good constitution.
tgt_text.3298: I say that there is something of this kind both in the body and in the soul, which causes the body and the soul to appear to be in a good condition, when they are any thing but so.
tgt_text.3302: Come now, if I can, I will explain to you more clearly what I mean.
tgt_text.3303: As there are two subject matters, I say there are two arts :
tgt_text.3304: and that which relates to the soul I call politi­ cal, but that which relates to the body I am not able to de­ scribe to you off-hand by one name ;
tgt_text.3305: but of the culture of the body, which is one, I say there are two divisions, one gymnas­ tics, the other medicine.
tgt_text.3306: But in the political art I lay down legislation, as corresponding to gymnastics, and the judicial to medicine.
tgt_text.3307: Now these respectively communicate with each other, as being concerned about the same subject, medicine with gymnastics, and the judicial art with legislation ;
tgt_text.3308: yet they in some respect differ from each other.
tgt_text.3309: These then being four, and always taking the best possible care, the former of the body, and the latter of the soul, flattery perceiving this, I do not say knowing, but sagaciously guessing it, and having divided itself fourfold, and having stealthily put on the garb of each of these divisions, feigns itself to be that which it has put on;
tgt_text.3310: and it is not in the least concerned for what is best;
tgt_text.3311: but by means of that which is most pleasant, captivates and seduces ignorance, so as to appear to be of great value.
tgt_text.3312: 45. Cookery,' therefore, puts on the garb of medicine, and pretends that it knows the aliment best for the -body.
tgt_text.3313: So that if a cook and a physician had to contend before boys, or before men as foolish as boys, which of the two was acquainted with good and bad:
tgt_text.3314: aliments, the physician or the cook, the physician would die of.
tgt_text.3317: , and I say that a thing of this kind is base, Polus, (for I say this to you,) because it looks to what is agreeable without regard to what is best;
tgt_text.3318: and I affirm that it is not an art, but skill, because it has no know­ ledge of the things which it employs, what they severally are in their nature, so that it is unable to tell the use of each.
tgt_text.3319: But I do not call that an art which is a thing without reason.
tgt_text.3320: If you are doubtful about these things, I am willing to give you a reason for them.
tgt_text.3321: The flattery, then, pertaining to cookery, as I have said, is concealed under medicine;
tgt_text.3322: and in the same manner, under gymnastics, personal decoration, which is mis­ chievous, deceitful, ignoble, and illiberal, deceiving by means of gestures and colours, by smoothness and outward appear­ ance ;
tgt_text.3323: so as to make men put on an adventitious beauty, and neglect that which is their own, and is acquired by gymnas­ tics.
tgt_text.3324: 46. That I may not, then, be prolix, I wish to tell you, after the manner of geometricians, (for perhaps you can now follow me,) that what personal decoration is to gymnastics, that is cookery to medicine:
tgt_text.3325: or rather thus, that what personal decoration is to gymnastics, that is sophistry to legislation, and that what cookery is to medicine, that is rhetoric to jus­ tice.
tgt_text.3326: As I have said, they are thus different in their nature :
tgt_text.3327: but as they are proximate to each otherk, sophists and rhetori­ cians are confounded with legislators and judges, and are em­ ployed about the same things, and know not what to make of themselves, nor other men of them.
tgt_text.3328: For, if the soul did not preside over the body, but.
tgt_text.3329: the body over itself, and cook­ ery and medicine were not examined into and distinguished by the soul, but the body itself decided, estimating things by its own gratifications, that tenet of Anaxagoras would prevail ex­ tensively, friend Polus, (for you surely are acquainted with it,) that is, all things would be confounded together, things medi­ cinal, and healthy, and pertaining to cookery, being undistin­ guished from each other.
tgt_text.3330: 47. You have heard, therefore, what I consider rhetoric to be, corresponding to cookery in the soul, as that in the body.
tgt_text.3331: Perhaps, however, I have acted absurdly, in that, though I do not allow you to make a long speech, I myself have extended mine to a great length.
tgt_text.3332: But I deserve to be pardoned:
tgt_text.3333: for when I spoke briefly you did not understand me, nor were you able to make use of the an­ swer that I gave you, but required an explanation.
tgt_text.3334: If, there­ fore, when you answer, I in my turn shall not know what to make of it, do you also prolong your discourse :
tgt_text.3335: but, if I do know, suffer me to do so ;
tgt_text.3337: And now, if you can make any use of this answer, do so.
tgt_text.3340: Does rhetoric appear to you to be flattery ?
tgt_text.3342: I said, indeed, that it was a division of flattery.
tgt_text.3343: But do not you remember, Polus, though so young?
tgt_text.3344: What will you do by and by ?
tgt_text.3346: Does it seem to you, then, that good rhetoricians are to be esteemed as vile flatterers in cities ?
tgt_text.3348: Do you ask this as a question, or are you beginning an argument?
tgt_text.3352: They appear to me to be of no estimation at all.
tgt_text.3354: How to be of no estimation?
tgt_text.3355: Have they not the greatest power in cities ?
tgt_text.3357: Not, if you mean that to have power is a good to him who possesses it.
tgt_text.3361: In that case, rhetoricians appear to me to possess the least power of all men in cities.
tgt_text.3364: do they not, like tyrants, slay whomever they please, and deprive of their property, and banish from cities whomever they think fit ?
tgt_text.3366: By the do-, Polus, I am doubtful with respect to each of the things you say, whether you assert these things your­ self, and declare your own opinion, or ask me.
tgt_text.3371: Then you ask me two questions at once.
tgt_text.3373: Did you not just now say, that rhetoricians, like ty­ rants, slay whomever they please, and deprive them of their property, and banish from cities whomever they think fit ?
tgt_text.3376: I say, then, that these are two questions, and I will give you an answer to both.
tgt_text.3377: For I affirm, Polus, that rhetoricians and tyrants have very little power in cities, as I just now said:
tgt_text.3378: for they do scarcely any thing that they wish, though they do what to them appears to be best.
tgt_text.3380: Is not this, then, to possess great power ?
tgt_text.3382: It is not, at least as Polus says.
tgt_text.3385: On the contrary, I say it is.
tgt_text.3387: For you said that to have great power is a good to him who possesses it.
tgt_text.3391: Do you think, then, it is a good for any one to do what appears to him to be best, when he is void of understand­ ing ?
tgt_text.3392: And do you call this to possess great power ?
tgt_text.3393: Socr. Prove, therefore, that rhetoricians are possessed of understanding, and that rhetoric is an art, and not flattery, if you mean to confute me.
tgt_text.3394: But, if you will leave me uncon­ futed, rhetoricians and tyrants, who do in cities whatever they please, will derive no good from thence.
tgt_text.3395: Power is, as you say, good;
tgt_text.3396: but to do, without understanding, whatever one pleases, you yourself admit is an evil.
tgt_text.3401: How then can rhetoricians or tyrants have great power in cities, unless Socrates is persuaded by Polus to admit that they do what they wish ?
tgt_text.3405: I deny that they do what they wish :
tgt_text.3408: Did you not just now admit that they do what appears to them to be best ?
tgt_text.3412: They do, therefore, what they wish.
tgt_text.3415: But they do what appears best to them ?
tgt_text.3419: You speak absurdly and monstrously, Socrates.
tgt_text.3421: Do not accuse me, most excellent Polus, that I may address you in your own style;
tgt_text.3422: but, if you have any other question to ask me, shew that I am deceived;
tgt_text.3423: if not, do you answer me.
tgt_text.3425: I am willing to answer, in order that I may know what you mean.
tgt_text.3427: Whether, then, do men appear to you to wish the thing that they do from time to time, or that for the sake of which they do the thing that they do ?
tgt_text.3428: As for instance, do those who drink medicine from physicians appear to you to wish the thing that they do, viz., to drink the medicine, and suffer pain, or do they wish to be well, for the sake of which they drink the medicine ?
tgt_text.3430: It is clear they wish to be well, for the sake of which they drink the medicine.
tgt_text.3432: In like manner those who sail on the sea, and those who carry on any other commercial business, do not wish the thing that they do from time to time:
tgt_text.3433: for who wishes to sail and to encounter danger, and to be harassed with business;
tgt_text.3434: but the object for which they sail is to acquire riches;
tgt_text.3435: for they sail for the sake of riches.
tgt_text.3438: Is it not so then in all cases ?
tgt_text.3439: whosoever does any thing for the sake of some thing else, does not wish the thing that he does, but that for the sake of which he does it.
tgt_text.3442: Is there any thing in the world, then, that is not either good or evil, or between these, neither good nor evil ?
tgt_text.3444: It must needs be so, Socrates.
tgt_text.3446: Do you not admit then, that wisdom, and health, and riches, and other things of the same kind, are good, but their contraries evil ?
tgt_text.3450: By the things that are neither good nor evil do you not mean such as sometimes partake of good,sometimes of evil, and sometimes of neither, as to sit, to walk, to run, and to sail, and again, stones, wood, and other things of the same kind?
tgt_text.3451: Are not these the things that you mean?
tgt_text.3452: Or do you call certain other things neither good nor evil ?
tgt_text.3456: Whether, therefore, do men, when they do these inter­ mediate things, do them for the sake of the good, or the good for the sake of the intermediate.
tgt_text.3458: The intermediate, surely, for the sake of the good.
tgt_text.3460: Pursuing the good, therefore, we both walk when we walk, thinking it better, and, on the contrary, we stand when we stand, for the sake of the same thing, viz., the good.
tgt_text.3464: Do we not, therefore, if we slay any one, slay, or banish, or deprive him of his possessions, thinking that it is better for us to do so than not ?
tgt_text.3468: They, therefore, who do these things do them all for the sake of good.
tgt_text.3472: Are we not agreed, then, that we do not wish those things which we do for the sake of something else, but that for the sake of which we do them ?
tgt_text.3476: We do not, then, wish simply to slay, or banish from cities, or deprive any one of his possessions ;
tgt_text.3477: but if these things are useful we wish to do them, but if they are hurtful we do not wish to do them.
tgt_text.3478: For we wish, as you admit, things that are good, but we do not wish such as are neither good nor evil, nor such as are evil.
tgt_text.3480: Do I seem to you, Polus, to speak the truth, or not?
tgt_text.3485: Since then we are agreed on these things, if any one slays, banishes from a city, or deprives another of his posses sions, whether he is a tyrant or a rhetorician, thinking that it is better for him so to do, though it is really worse, he surely does what seems fit to him :
tgt_text.3490: Does he, then, do what he wishes, if these things are really evil ?
tgt_text.3493: He does not appear to me to do what he wishes.
tgt_text.3495: Is it possible, then, that such a man can have great power in the supposed city, if, according to your admis­ sion, to have great power is a good ?
tgt_text.3499: I spoke truly, then, when I said that it is possible for a man to do what he pleases in a city, and yet not have great power, nor do what he wishes.
tgt_text.3501: As if, Socrates, you yourself would not like to be allowed to do what you please in a city, rather than not, and would not be envious when you saw any one either slay­ ing whom he pleased, or taking away his possessions, or putting him in bonds.
tgt_text.3503: Do you mean justly or unjustly?
tgt_text.3505: Whichever he should do, is he not in either case to be envied ?
tgt_text.3508: Because it is not right, either to envy those that are not to be envied, or the wretched;
tgt_text.3512: Does such appear to you to be the case with the men of whom I am speaking ?
tgt_text.3517: Does he, then, who slays whom he pleases, slaying hiin justly, appear to you to be wretched, and an object of pity ?
tgt_text.3520: nor indeed is he to be envied.
tgt_text.3522: Did you not say just now that he was wretched ?
tgt_text.3524: I said, my friend, that he is wretched who slays an­ other unjustly, and more than that, to be pitied;
tgt_text.3525: but that he who slays another justly is not to be envied.
tgt_text.3527: He surely who dies unjustly is to be pitied, and is wretched.
tgt_text.3528: Socr. Less so, Polus, than he who slays him;
tgt_text.3529: and less than he who dies justly?
tgt_text.3534: because to act unjustly is the greatest of evils.
tgt_text.3536: But is this really the greatest of evils?
tgt_text.3537: Is it not a greater evil to suffer unjustly?
tgt_text.3541: Had you, then, rather suffer unjustly than act un­ justly?
tgt_text.3543: I should wish neither of these:
tgt_text.3544: but if I must neces­ sarily either act unjustly or suffer unjustly, I should choose rather to suffer unjustly than to act unjustly.
tgt_text.3546: Would you not, then, consent to be a tyrant?
tgt_text.3548: I would not, if by being a tyrant you mean the same that I do.
tgt_text.3550: I mean by it what I just now said, to have the power to do in a city whatever one pleases;
tgt_text.3551: to slay and banish, and do every thing according to one's own pleasure.
tgt_text.3553: My excellent friend, attend to what I say, and confute me if you can.
tgt_text.3554: If, when the forum is full, I should take a dagger under my arm, and say to you, Polus, a certain wonderful power and tyranny has just now fallen to my lot:
tgt_text.3555: for, if it seems fit to me that any one of these men whom you see ought immediately to die, he shall die;
tgt_text.3556: and if it seems fit to me that any one of them ought to have his head broken, he shall immediately have it broken;
tgt_text.3557: or if that his garment should be torn to pieces, it shall be torn to pieces:
tgt_text.3558: so great is the power I possess in the city.
tgt_text.3559: And if, on your dis­ believing me, I should shew you the dagger, perhaps, on see­ ing it, you would say:
tgt_text.3560: According to this, Socrates, all men may have great power, since any house that you please might be burnt in this way, and even the dock-yards of the Athe­ nians, and the triremes, and all the shipping, as well public as private.
tgt_text.3561: But surely this is not to possess great power, to do whatever one pleases:
tgt_text.3566: Can you tell me, then, why you blame a power of this kind ?
tgt_text.3573: Because it must needs be that one who acts thus should be punished.
tgt_text.3575: But is not the being punished an evil ?
tgt_text.3578: Therefore, my excellent friend, to have great power appears to you to be, when advantage attends one's doing what one pleases, and then it is a good;
tgt_text.3579: and this, as it seems, is to have great power;
tgt_text.3580: but if not, it is an evil, and to have little power.
tgt_text.3582: Are we not agreed that it is sometimes better to do the things which we just now spoke of, to slay, to banish men, and deprive them of their property, and sometimes not ?
tgt_text.3586: This, then, as it seems, is agreed on both by you and me?
tgt_text.3588: When, then, do you say it is better to do these things ?
tgt_text.3589: Tell me what limit you establish ?
tgt_text.3591: Do you, Socrates, answer this question:
tgt_text.3593: I say, then, Polus, since it is more agreeable to you to hear it from me, when any one does these things justly, it is better, but when unjustly, it is worse.
tgt_text.3594: Pol. Forsooth, it is difficult to confute you, Socrates!
tgt_text.3595: but could not even a child convince you that you do not speak the truth ?
tgt_text.3597: I should be very much obliged to the child, and equally so to you, if you can confute me, and free me from my extra­ vagances.
tgt_text.3598: But be not weary in obliging a man who is your friend, but confute me.
tgt_text.3600: However, Socrates, there is no need to confute you by ancient examples.
tgt_text.3601: For things that have recently happened are sufficient to confute you, and to prove that many men who have acted unjustly are happy.
tgt_text.3605: Do you not see, for instance, this Archelaus, son of Perdiccas, ruler of Macedonia ?
tgt_text.3607: If not, at all events I hear of him.
tgt_text.3609: Does he appear to you to be happy or miserable ?
tgt_text.3612: for I have never yet had any intercourse with him.
tgt_text.3615: if you had intercourse with him, should you know ?
tgt_text.3616: And do you not know otherwise, from the cir­ cumstances of the case, that he is happy ?
tgt_text.3619: It is evident then, Socrates, you will say, that you do not even know whether the great king is happy ?
tgt_text.3621: And I should say the truth.
tgt_text.3622: For I do not know what his state is with regard to enlightenment and justice.
tgt_text.3625: Does all happiness consist in this ?
tgt_text.3628: For I say that an honest and good man or woman is happy;
tgt_text.3629: but an unjust and wicked one is miserable.
tgt_text.3631: This Archelaus, then, is miserable, according to your account ?
tgt_text.3633: At least, my friend, if he is unjust.
tgt_text.3636: But how can he be otherwise than unjust, who had no right to the empire which he now possesses, as he was born of a woman who was the.
tgt_text.3637: slave of Alcetas, brother of Perdiccas, and according to justice was the slave of Alcetas, and, if he had wished to do what is just, would have served Alcetas as a slave, and would have been happy, according to your account ?
tgt_text.3638: whereas now he has become wonderfully miserable, since he has committed the greatest injustice.
tgt_text.3639: For, first of all, having sent for this his master and uncle, as if he would restore the government which Perdiccas had taken from him, and having entertained and intoxicated both him and his son Alexander, his own cousin, and nearly his equal in age, he forced them into a carriage, and having carried them off by night, had their throats cut and made away with them both.
tgt_text.3640: And after he had committed these wrongs, he was not aware that he had become most miserable, and did not repent, but shortly after­ wards, he did not wish to become happy by nurturing his legi­ timate brother, the son of Perdiccas, a child about seven years of age, to whom the government of right belonged, and by restoring it to him;
tgt_text.3641: but having thrown him into a well, and suffocated him, he told his mother Cleopatra that he had fallen in in pursuing a goose, and so met with his death.
tgt_text.3642: 60. Where­ fore since he has committed the greatest wrongs of all in Mace­ donia, he is the most miserable of all the Macedonians, and not the most happy.
tgt_text.3643: And perhaps there are some among the Athenians, beginning with you, who would rather be any other of the Macedonians than Archelaus.
tgt_text.3645: At the beginning of our conference, Polus, I praised you, because you appeared to me to be well instructed in rhe­ toric, though you had neglected the art of dialectics.
tgt_text.3646: And now, what else is this reasoning, by which even a child could confute me, and I, as you suppose, am now confuted by this reasoning of yours, when I said that a man who acts unjustly is not happy?
tgt_text.3648: For I do not grant you any one of the things you assert.
tgt_text.3650: Because you are not willing to do so;
tgt_text.3651: though it ap­ pears to you as I say.
tgt_text.3653: My excellent friend, you attempt to confute me rheto­ rically, like those who think they confute their adversaries in courts of justice.
tgt_text.3654: For there some fancy they confute others , when they produce many reputable witnesses in favour of what they say, whereas the adverse party produces some one only, or none at all.
tgt_text.3655: 61. But this mode of confutation is worth nothing with reference to truth.
tgt_text.3656: For sometimes a man may be borne down by the false testimony of many witnesses who seem to be somewhat.
tgt_text.3657: And now, with respect to what you say, almost all the Athenians and strangers will agree with you, and if you wish to produce witnesses against me to prove that I do not speak the truth, there will testify for you, if you wish it, Nicias, son of Niceratus, and his brothers with him, who gave the tripods that stand in a row in the temple of Bac­ chus ;
tgt_text.3658: or again, if you wish it, Aristocrates, son of Scellius, who gave that beautiful offering in the temple of Pythian Apollo;
tgt_text.3659: or if you wish it, the whole house of Pericles, or any other family, that you may think proper to choose out of this city.
tgt_text.3660: But I, who am but one, do not agree with you.
tgt_text.3661: For you do not convince me by arguments, but producing many false witnesses against me, you endeavour to eject me from my substance and the truth.
tgt_text.3662: But I, unless I shall be able to ad­ duce you, who are one, as a witness agreeing with what I say, shall think that I have accomplished nothing worthy of men­ tion with respect to the subject of our discussion;
tgt_text.3663: nor shall I think that you have done so, unless I, being one, alone testify for you, and you dismiss all those others.
tgt_text.3664: 62. This, then, is one mode of refutation, as you and many others think:
tgt_text.3665: but there is also another mode, which, on the contrary, I adopt.
tgt_text.3666: Let us, therefore, compare them with each other, and consider whether they differ at all from one another.
tgt_text.3667: For the matters about which we differ are by no means trifling;
tgt_text.3668: but they are indeed such as to know which is most honourable, and not to know most disgraceful, for the sum of them is to know, or to be ignorant, who is happy, and who is not.
tgt_text.3669: For instance, in the first place, with respect to the subject of our present dis­ cussion, you think it possible that a man may be happy who acts unjustly and is unjust;
tgt_text.3670: since you think that Archelaus, though unjust, is happy.
tgt_text.3671: Must we not suppose that such is your opinion ?
tgt_text.3674: But I say it is impossible.
tgt_text.3675: On this one point, then, we differ.
tgt_text.3677: But will he who acts unjustly be happy if he meet with justice and is punished ?
tgt_text.3679: By no means, for in that case he would be most miserable.
tgt_text.3681: If, therefore, he who acts unjustly does not meet with the punishment he deserves, according to your account he will be happy.
tgt_text.3684: 63. Socr. But, according to my opinion, Polus, he who acts unjustly, and is unjust, is in every way miserable ;
tgt_text.3685: though more miserable if he does not suffer punishment, and does not meet with chastisement for his unjust actions;
tgt_text.3686: but less miser­ able if he suffers punishment, and meets with his just deserts both from gods and men.
tgt_text.3688: You attempt, Socrates, to advance strange para­ doxes.
tgt_text.3690: Yet I shall endeavour, my friend, to make you say the same things as I do :
tgt_text.3691: for I consider you as a friend.
tgt_text.3692: Now, then, the things about which we differ are these:
tgt_text.3694: I said in a former part of our discussion, that to commit an injustice is worse than to suffer one.
tgt_text.3697: But you say it is worse to suffer an injustice.
tgt_text.3699: And I said that they who act unjustly are miserable, and was confuted by you.
tgt_text.3703: At least as you think, Polus.
tgt_text.3705: And I probably thought the truth.
tgt_text.3707: But you, on the contrary, said that they who act un­ justly are happy, if they do not suffer punishment.
tgt_text.3710: But I say that they are most miserable;
tgt_text.3711: and that they who suffer punishment are less so.
tgt_text.3712: Do you wish to re­ fute this also ?
tgt_text.3714: But this is more difficult to refute than the former, Socrates.
tgt_text.3716: By no means, Polus, but it is impossible;
tgt_text.3717: for truth can never be refuted.
tgt_text.3720: If a man should be detected acting unjustly, as in attempting to compass absolute power, and being detected should be put to the torture, be mutilated, and have his eyes burnt out, and after having himself suffered many other great and various torments, and having moreover seen his children and wife suffer the same, should at last be crucified, or covered with pitch and burnt, will he be more happy, than if, having escaped punishment, he should become a tyrant, and ruling in the city, should pass through life doing whatever he pleases, being envied, and accounted happy, both by citizens and strangers ?
tgt_text.3721: Do you say that it is impossible to refute these things ?
tgt_text.3723: You are now trying to terrify me, noble Polus, and do not refute me;
tgt_text.3724: but just now you adduced witnesses.
tgt_text.3725: How­ ever, remind me of a trifling circumstance;
tgt_text.3726: did you say, if a person should attempt unjustly to compass absolute power ?
tgt_text.3730: In that case, neither of them will ever be happier than the other, neither he who has unjustly acquired absolute power, nor he who has been punished.
tgt_text.3731: For, of two miserable per­ sons, one cannot be happier than the other;
tgt_text.3732: but he is more miserable who escapes punishment and acquires absolute power.
tgt_text.3735: Is this another species of refutation, when any one asserts any thing, to laugh at him, and not refute him ?
tgt_text.3737: Do you not think you are already refuted.
tgt_text.3738: Socrates, when you say such things as no man in the world would assert ?
tgt_text.3739: for ask any one of these.
tgt_text.3740: Socr. Polus, I am not among the number of politicians:
tgt_text.3741: and last year, happening to be chosen a senator, since my tribe held the presidency and it was necessary for me to col­ lect the votes, I occasioned laughter, because I did not know how to collect them.
tgt_text.3742: Do not, then, require me to collect the votes of those who are present.
tgt_text.3743: But if you have no better mode of refutation than this, as I just now said, give the ques­ tion up to me in my turn, and make trial of that mode of refu­ tation which I think ought to be adopted.
tgt_text.3744: For I know how to procure one witness of what I say, that is, the person with whom I am discoursing, but I let alone the multitude;
tgt_text.3745: and I know how to take the vote of one person, but I do not even discourse with the multitude.
tgt_text.3746: Consider, then, whether you are willing in your turn to give me an opportunity of refuting by answering the questions I shall put to you.
tgt_text.3747: For I think, that you and I, and other men, are of opinion, that to commit injustice is worse than to suffer it;
tgt_text.3748: and not to be punished, than to be punished.
tgt_text.3750: But I, on the contrary, think that neither myself nor any other man is of this opinion.
tgt_text.3751: For would you rather suffer injustice than commit it ?
tgt_text.3753: Yes, and you, and all other men.
tgt_text.3756: neither would you, nor I, nor any other man.
tgt_text.3761: For I am anxious to know what you will say.
tgt_text.3763: Tell me then, that you may know, as if I asked you from the beginning:
tgt_text.3764: whether does it appear to you, Polus, worse to commit an injustice or to suffer one ?
tgt_text.3766: To suffer one, in my opinion.
tgt_text.3769: whether is it more base to commit an injustice or to suffer one ?
tgt_text.3774: Is it not, therefore, worse, since it is more base ?
tgt_text.3778: You do not think, as it seems, that the beautiful and the good, and the evil and the base, are the same ?
tgt_text.3782: But what do you say to-this?
tgt_text.3783: Beautiful things in general, such as bodies, colours, forms, sounds, and pursuits, do you call them severally beautiful, without reference to any thing else ?
tgt_text.3784: As, for instance, first of all, with respect to beau­ tiful bodies, do you not say that they are beautiful, on account of their usefulness, in reference to the particular thing for which each is useful, or on account of some pleasure, if in being seen they give delight to the beholders ?
tgt_text.3785: Have you any thing else besides this to say respecting beauty of body ?
tgt_text.3790: Do you not, then, denominate all other things in the same manner beautiful, such as forms and colours, either on account of some pleasure, or utility, or both ?
tgt_text.3794: And is not the case the same as to sounds, and every thing that relates to music ?
tgt_text.3797: And moreover, with respect to laws and pursuits, they surely are beautiful, for no other reason except that they are either useful, or pleasant, or both ?
tgt_text.3801: And is it not the same with the beauty of the sciences ?
tgt_text.3803: And now, Socrates, you define beautifully, in defining the beautiful by pleasure and good.
tgt_text.3805: Must not, therefore, the base be defined by the con­ trary, by pain and evil ?
tgt_text.3809: When, therefore, of two beautiful things, one is more beautiful than the other, it is more beautiful because it excels in one or both of these, either in pleasure, or utility, or both.
tgt_text.3812: And when of two things one is more base than the other, it must be more base because it exceeds in pain or evil:
tgt_text.3816: what did we say just now respecting committing injustice and suffering it ?
tgt_text.3817: Did you not say that to suffer injustice is more evil, but to commit it, more base ?
tgt_text.3821: Therefore, since it is more base to commit injustice than to suffer it, it must be more base because it is more pain­ ful and exceeds in pain, or evil, or both.
tgt_text.3826: First, then, let us consider whether to commit injus­ tice exceeds in pain the suffering it;
tgt_text.3827: and whether they who commit injustice feel greater pain than they who suffer it.
tgt_text.3829: This is by no means the case, Socrates.
tgt_text.3831: It does not, then, exceed in pain ?
tgt_text.3835: Therefore, if it does not exceed in pain, it will no longer exceed in both.
tgt_text.3839: It remains, therefore, that it exceeds in the other.
tgt_text.3844: Socr. Since, therefore, to commit injustice exceeds in evil, it must be more evil than to suffer injustice.
tgt_text.3848: Was it not admitted by men in general, and by you to me formerly, that it is more base to commit injustice than to suffer it?
tgt_text.3849: Pol. Yes.Socr. Now, however, it appears to be worse.
tgt_text.3853: Would you, then, rather choose that which is worse and more base, than that which is less so ?
tgt_text.3854: Do not hesitate to answer, Polus, (for you will not be injured by so doing,) but answer, giving yourself up generously to the discussion as to a physician;
tgt_text.3855: and either admit or deny the question I ask.
tgt_text.3857: Then I should not rather choose it, Socrates.
tgt_text.3859: Would any other man in the world ?
tgt_text.3861: To me it appears not, according to what has been said.
tgt_text.3863: I therefore said truly, that neither you, nor I, nor any other man in the world, would rather choose to commit in­ justice than to suffer it;
tgt_text.3864: for it is worse to do so.
tgt_text.3868: You see then, Polus, that my mode of proof when compared with your mode of proof, does not at all resemble it;
tgt_text.3869: but all others agree with you, except myself.
tgt_text.3870: For my part you alone are sufficient for my purpose, agreeing with me and testifying for me ;
tgt_text.3871: and I, having asked your opinion only, disregard that of others.
tgt_text.3872: Let this then be settled between us.
tgt_text.3873: And next, let us proceed to consider that which we doubted about in the second place, viz.
tgt_text.3875: greatest of evils for one who has committed injustice to be punished, as you thought, or whether it is not a greater evil not to be punished, as I thought.
tgt_text.3876: And let us consider it thus:
tgt_text.3877: To suffer punishment and to be justly chastised, when one has committed injustice, do you not call the same thing?
tgt_text.3880: Can you say, then, that all just things are not beautiful, so far as they are just?
tgt_text.3881: When you have well considered, answer me.
tgt_text.3883: It appears to me that they are, Socrates.
tgt_text.3886: When a man does any thing, must there not necessarily be something which is passive to him as an agent ?
tgt_text.3890: And does not the patient suffer what the agent does, and just such a thing as the agent does?
tgt_text.3892: If any one strikes, is it not necessary that something should be struck ?
tgt_text.3896: And if the striker strikes hard or swiftly, must not the thing struck be stricken accordingly ?
tgt_text.3900: That which is struck, then, undergoes a passion cor­ responding to that which the striker does.
tgt_text.3902: In like manner, if any one burns, is it not neces­ sary that something should be burnt?
tgt_text.3906: And if he burns vehemently or painfully, that which is burnt must be burnt according as the burner burns ?
tgt_text.3910: So, if any one cuts any thing, is not the reasoning the same ?
tgt_text.3914: And if the cut is large or deep, or painful, that which is cut is cut with such a cut as the cutter cuts.
tgt_text.3918: In a word, then, see if you grant what I just now said respecting every thing, viz., that according as the agent does, so the patient suffers.
tgt_text.3922: These things, then, being agreed on, whether is the being punished, to suffer, or to do something ?
tgt_text.3924: Necessarily, Socrates, it is to suffer.
tgt_text.3926: Must it not, therefore, be by some agent ?
tgt_text.3931: But does not he who chastises rightly, chastise justly ?
tgt_text.3934: Socr. Doing what is just, or not?
tgt_text.3938: Then, does not he who is chastised, when he is deservedly punished, suffer justly ?
tgt_text.3942: But what is just has been acknowledged to be beautiful.
tgt_text.3945: Of these, then, the one does, and the other, he that is chastised, suffers that which is beautiful.
tgt_text.3949: for that which is beauti­ ful is either pleasant or useful.
tgt_text.3953: He therefore who is punished suffers that which is good.
tgt_text.3960: Is it with such a benefit as I suppose?
tgt_text.3961: Does he be-, come better as to his soul, since he is chastised justly ?
tgt_text.3965: He, therefore, who is punished is freed from a vice of the soul.
tgt_text.3968: Is he not freed, then, from the greatest evil?
tgt_text.3970: in the condition of a man's property do you perceive any other evil than poverty ?
tgt_text.3973: Socr. Well, in the constitution of the body?
tgt_text.3974: would you say that weakness, disease, deformity, and the like, are evils ?
tgt_text.3978: Do you not think, too, that there is a certain depra­ vity in the soul ?
tgt_text.3982: Do you not then call this injustice, ignorance, coward­ ice, and the like ?
tgt_text.3986: Have you not said, then, that of these three, property, body, and soul, there are three corresponding evils, poverty, disease, injustice ?Pol.
tgt_text.3989: Then which of these evils is the most base ?
tgt_text.3990: Is it not injustice, and, in a word, the depravity of the soul?
tgt_text.3994: But, if it is most base, then is it not also the worst ?
tgt_text.3998: In every case, that which is most base is so because, from what has been before admitted, it occasions the greatest pain, or harm, or both.
tgt_text.4002: But injustice and the whole depravity of the soul, have been just now admitted by us to be most base.
tgt_text.4006: Is it not, therefore, the most troublesome and most base of these depravities, because it exceeds either in trouble­ someness or hurtfulness, or both ?
tgt_text.4010: Is then the being unjust, intemperate, cowardly, and ignorant, more painful than to be poor and diseased ?
tgt_text.4012: It does not appear so to me, Socrates, from what has been said.
tgt_text.4014: The depravity of the soul, then, is the most base of all, because it exceeds the others by some extraordinarily great harm and wonderful evil, since, according to your argu­ ment, it is not exceeded in painfulness.
tgt_text.4017: Socr. But, surely, that which exceeds in the greatest harm­ fulness must be the greatest evil of all ?
tgt_text.4021: Then injustice, intemperance, and the other depravi­ ties of the soul, are the greatest evils of all.
tgt_text.4025: What art, then, frees from poverty?
tgt_text.4026: Is it not that of money-making ?
tgt_text.4036: If in this way vou cannot readily answer, consider it thus:
tgt_text.4037: whither, and to whom, do we take those that are diseased in body ?
tgt_text.4041: Whether those who act unjustly, and are intemperate ?
tgt_text.4043: Do you mean, to the judges ?
tgt_text.4045: Is it not, then, that they may be punished ?
tgt_text.4049: Do not then those who chastise rightly chastise by employing a certain justice ?
tgt_text.4052: The art of money-making, therefore, frees from poverty, medicine from disease, and justice from intemperance and in­ justice.
tgt_text.4056: Which of these, therefore, is the most beautiful ?
tgt_text.4060: The art of money-making, medicine, and justice.
tgt_text.4061: Pol. Justice, Socrates, is far superior.
tgt_text.4063: Does it not, then, produce the greatest pleasure, or utility, or both, since it is the most beautiful rPol.
tgt_text.4065: Is it, then, pleasant to be under the care of a physician ?
tgt_text.4066: and do they who are under such charge rejoice ?
tgt_text.4068: It does not appear so to me.
tgt_text.4075: For they are freed from a great evil;
tgt_text.4076: so that it is advantageous to endure pain and be restored to health.
tgt_text.4080: Would the man then, thus be most happy with respect to his body who is under the care of a physician, or who is not diseased at all ?
tgt_text.4082: Clearly he that is not diseased.
tgt_text.4084: For this is not happiness, as it seems, the being freed from evil;
tgt_text.4085: but the never possessing it at all.
tgt_text.4090: Of two men that have evil, either in body or soul, which is the more miserable, he that is under the care of a physician, and is freed from the evil, or he that is not under the care of a physician, and retains the evil ?
tgt_text.4092: It appears to me, he that is not under the care of a physician.
tgt_text.4094: And is not punishment the being freed from the greatest evil, depravity ?
tgt_text.4098: For justice produces a sound mind, makes men more just, and becomes the medicine of depravity ?
tgt_text.4100: Yes.76. Socr. He, then, is most happy who has no vice in his soul, since this is proved to be the greatest of evils.
tgt_text.4104: The second, surely, is he who is freed from it.
tgt_text.4108: But this is he who is admonished, reproved, and punished.
tgt_text.4110: He, therefore, lives worst, who is afflicted with in­ justice, and is not freed from it.
tgt_text.4114: Is not, then, he one who, having committed the greatest injustice, and employing the greatest injustice, con­ trives that he may be neither admonished, nor chastised, nor punished, as you said was the case with Archelaus, and other tyrants, rhetoricians, and powerful men ?
tgt_text.4118: For these, my excellent friend, have managed much the same as one who being afflicted with the worst diseases should contrive not to have his bodily maladies corrected or subjected to medical treatment, fearing, as if he were a child, to be burnt and cut, because these operations are painful.
tgt_text.4119: Does it not appear so to you ?
tgt_text.4122: Socr. Being ignorant, as it seems, of what health is, and a good habit of the body.
tgt_text.4123: 77. Now from what we have just agreed on, Polus, those who flee from punishment appear to do something of this kind;
tgt_text.4124: they look to the pain attending it, but are blind to its utility, and are ignorant how much more miserable than an unhealthy body it is to dwell with an un­ healthy soul, that is corrupt, unjust, and impious.
tgt_text.4125: Whence they do every thing that they may not be punished, nor freed from the greatest evil, procuring for themselves riches and friends, and the power of speaking as persuasively as possible.
tgt_text.4126: But if we have agreed on what is true, Polus, do you perceive what consequences result from our discourse r do you wish that we should draw the conclusions from them ?
tgt_text.4128: I do, unless you think otherwise.
tgt_text.4130: Does it not follow that injustice and to act unjustly is the greatest evil ?
tgt_text.4134: And to suffer punishment was proved to be a means of freedom from this evil.
tgt_text.4138: But not to suffer punishment is a continuance of the evil.
tgt_text.4141: To act unjustly, therefore, is the second of evils in magnitude;
tgt_text.4142: but to act unjustly and not to suffer punishment is the greatest and chief of all evils.
tgt_text.4146: Was not this the point, my friend, with respect to which we differed, you considering Archelaus happy, for that having committed the greatest injustice he suffers no punishment;
tgt_text.4147: but I on the contrary thinking, that whether Archelaus, or any other man whatever, is not punished when he commits injustice, he must needs be far more wretched than all other men, and that he who commits injustice is ever more wretched than he who suffers it, and he that is not punished than he that is.
