For he knows, I think, how to reason with himself, that it is uncertain whom of his pas­ sengers he has benefited by not allowing them to be drowned, and whom he has injured, knowing that he has not put them ashore in any respect better than they were when they went on board, either as to their souls or bodies.
tgt_text.5439: He therefore reasons with himself, that if one who is afflicted in his body with severe and incurable diseases should happen not to be drowned, such a man is indeed miserable for having escaped death, and has received no benefit from him;
tgt_text.5440: but if any one labours under many and incurable diseases in that which is more precious than the body, his soul, such a one ought u not to live, nor would he benefit him, if he saved him from the sea, or from a court of justice, or from any other danger, for he knows that it is not better for a depraved man to live, because he must needs live badly.
tgt_text.5441: For this reason, it is not usual for a pilot to boast, although he saves our lives ;
tgt_text.5442: nor, my admirable friend, is it usual for an engineer who is sometimes able to save, no less than a general of an army, not to mention a pilot or any other person;
tgt_text.5443: for sometimes he saves whole cities.
tgt_text.5444: Does it not appear to you that he is fit to be compared with a forensic orator ?
tgt_text.5445: though, if he chose to speak, Callicles, as you do, ex­ tolling his own art, he would overwhelm you with words, urging and exhorting you to the fitness of your becoming an engineer, for that other things are of no consequence ;
tgt_text.5446: and he would have enough to say.
tgt_text.5447: 145. You, however, would never­ theless despise him and his art, and, by way of reproach would call him an engineer, and would neither give your daughter to his son, nor accept his daughter for your son.
tgt_text.5448: Though, if from the reasons for which you praise your own art, on what just pretext do you despise the engineer, and the others whom I have just now mentioned ?
tgt_text.5449: I know that you would say you are better, and of a better family.
tgt_text.5450: But if that which is better is not what I say it is, but if excellence consists in this, for a man to save himself and his property, whatever kind of man he may be, then your contempt for the engineer and the pby­ sician, and for whatever other arts are pursued for the purpose of preservation, is ridiculous.
tgt_text.5451: But, my good friend, consider whether that which is noble and good is not something else than to save and be saved;
tgt_text.5452: and whether that principle, that one should live as long as one can, is not to be given up by one who is truly a man, and life not too fondly loved, but that leaving these things to the care of the deity, and believing the women, who say that no man can avoid his fate, one should consider this, by what means one may pass the remainder of one's life in the best possible manner, whether by conforming one's-self to the government under which one dwells.
tgt_text.5453: 146. And in that case whether it is right that you should resemble as much as possible the Athe­ nian people, if you wish to be dear to them, and to have great influence in their city?
tgt_text.5454: Consider whether this is advantageous to you and to me, lest, my admirable friend, we should suffer what they say the Thessalian x witches did, who drew down the moon, and our choice of this power in the city should be attended with the loss of what is dearest to us.
tgt_text.5455: If, however, you think that any man in the world can teach you any such art, as will cause you to have great power in this city, while you are unlike the character of the people, whether for the better or the worse, as appears to me, Callicles, you are not rightly advised.
tgt_text.5456: For you must not only be an imitator of, but like them in your natural disposition, if you mean to do any thing effectual towards gaining the friendship of the Athenian people, and, by Jupiter, you must towards that of the son of Pyrilampes.
tgt_text.5457: Whoever, therefore, shall make you most like them, will make you a politician and an orator, such as you desire to be.
tgt_text.5458: For all men are delighted with arguments suited to their own dispositions, but are angry with such as are strange to them;
tgt_text.5459: unless you, my dear friend, have any thing to say to the contrary.
tgt_text.5460: 147. Have we any objection to make to this, Callicles ?
tgt_text.5462: I do not know how it is, Socrates, you appear to me to speak well.
tgt_text.5463: Yet that which happens to most happens to me;
tgt_text.5464: I am not quite persuaded by you.
tgt_text.5466: For the love of the people, Callicles, dwelling in your soul, resists me;
tgt_text.5467: but perhaps, if we should often and more fully examine into these same matters, you would be persuaded.
tgt_text.5468: Remember, then, that we said there were two methods for the cultivation of each, both the body and the soul, and that one had reference to pleasure, but the other to that which is best, not by gratifying, but opposing the inclinations.
tgt_text.5469: Is not this what we before settled ?
tgt_text.5473: The one, then, that looks to pleasure is ignoble, and nothing else than flattery;
tgt_text.5476: Be it so, if you please.
tgt_text.5478: But the other endeavours that that which we cultivate may be made as excellent as possible, whether it be the body or the soul ?
tgt_text.5482: Must we then so endeavour to cultivate the city and the citizens, that we may make the citizens themselves as good as possible ?
tgt_text.5483: For without this, as we discovered before, it is of no advantage to confer any other benefit upon them, unless the mind of those who are about to receive either great riches, or dominion or any other power, be upright and good.
tgt_text.5484: Shall we lay this down, as being so ?
tgt_text.5486: Certainly, if it is more agreeable to you.
tgt_text.5489: If, therefore, Callicles, when setting about some public works, we were to exhort one another to works of archi­ tecture, as to very large buildings of walls, or docks or tem­ ples, would it be necessary that we should consider and ex­ amine ourselves, first, whether we are skilled or not in the art of architecture, and from whom we learnt it?
tgt_text.5490: Would this be necessary or not ?
tgt_text.5494: Then, secondly, we should consider this, whether we have ever constructed any private building, either for any one of our friends, or for ourselves, and whether this building is beautiful or ugly.
tgt_text.5495: And if on examination we found that our masters had been good and famous, and that we have con­ structed, in conjunction with our masters, many and beautiful buildings, and many privately by ourselves, after we had left our masters, in that case it would become men of sense to un­ dertake public works:
tgt_text.5496: but if we were not able to shew that we had a master, nor any building at all, or many and those of no account, it would surely in that case be foolish to attempt public works, and to exhort one another to undertake them.
tgt_text.5497: Shall we admit that this is well said, or not ?
tgt_text.5501: And is not this the case with all other things, and if, attempting to serve the public in the capacity of phy­ sicians, we should exhort each other, as if we were skilful phy­ sicians, should not you and I examine each other thus:
tgt_text.5502: By the gods, in what state is Socrates with respect to bodily health ?
tgt_text.5503: Has any other person, whether slave or freeman, been cured by Socrates of any disease ?
tgt_text.5504: And I too, I think, should make similar enquiries about you.
tgt_text.5505: And if we did not find that any one, whether stranger or citizen, man or woman, had been im­ proved in health by our means, by Jupiter, Callicles, would it not be truly ridiculous, that men should come to such a pitch of folly, as before they had practised much in private, as best they could, and had succeeded in many cases, and thoroughly exercised the art, to attempt to learn the potter's art in making a pitcher, as the proverb goes, and attempt to serve the public in the capacity of physician, and exhort others to do the same ?
tgt_text.5506: Does it not appear to you that it would be foolish to act thus ?
tgt_text.5511: But now, 0 best of men, since you have your­ self just now begun to busy yourself in affairs of state, and you exhort and reprove me because I do not busy myself about them, should we not examine each other;
tgt_text.5512: Come then, whom of the citizens has Callicles yet made better ?
tgt_text.5513: Is there any one who, being before depraved, unjust, intemperate, and foolish, has become upright and good through Callicles, whether stranger or citizen, slave or free-man?
tgt_text.5514: Tell me, Callicles, if any one should ask you these questions, what will you say ?
tgt_text.5515: Who will you say has been made better by associating with you ?
tgt_text.5516: Are you ashamed to answer, whether you have done any such -work while you were in a private capacity, before you at­ tempted to interfere in public affairs ?
tgt_text.5520: I do not ask you from a desire to cavil, but really wish­ ing to know in what way you think public affairs ought to be con­ ducted by us;
tgt_text.5521: whether on undertaking the management of affairs of state we ought to attend to any thing else than how we may become as good citizens as possible.
tgt_text.5522: Have we not already often admitted that a politician ought to do this ?
tgt_text.5523: Have we admitted it or not?
tgt_text.5527: 151. If, then, a good man ought to en­ deavour to procure this for his city, now call to mind and say with respect to those men whom you a little before mentioned, whether they still appear to you to have been good citizens, Pericles, Cimon, Miltiades and Themistocles.
tgt_text.5531: If, therefore, they were good citizens, it is evident that each of them made their fellow-citizens better instead of worse.
tgt_text.5536: When Pericles, therefore, began to speak in public, were the Athenians worse than when he addressed them for the last time ?
tgt_text.5540: There is no 'perhaps' in the case, my good friend, but this is a necessary consequence from what has been ad­ mitted, if he really was a good citizen.
tgt_text.5544: But tell me this moreover, whether the Athenians are supposed to have become better through Pericles, or quite the contrary, to have been corrupted by him.
tgt_text.5545: For so I hear, that Pericles made the Athenians idle, cowardly, talka­ tive and avaricious, having been the first to give them pay.
tgt_text.5547: You hear this, Socrates, from those whose ears have been bruised y.152.
tgt_text.5549: However, I no longer hear this, but I know well and so do you, that Pericles at first bore a high character, and that the Athenians passed no ignominious sentence upon him, when they were worse, but when by his means they had become upright and good, towards the close of the life of Pericles, they condemned him for peculation, and were on the point of sen­ tencing him to death, clearly as being a bad citizen.
tgt_text.5552: Was Pericles on this account a bad man ?
tgt_text.5554: Such an one, indeed, would be thought a bad manager of asses, horses, and oxen, if having received them, neither kicking, nor butting, nor biting, he should make them do all these things through vice.
tgt_text.5555: Does not every trainer of any ani­ mal whatever appear to you to be a bad one, who, having re­ ceived it gentle, has made it more vicious than he received it ?
tgt_text.5556: Does he appear so, or not ?
tgt_text.5558: Certainly, that I may gratify you.
tgt_text.5560: Gratify me, then, by answering this too, whether man is of the class of animals, or not ?
tgt_text.5564: Had not Pericles, then, the care of men ?
tgt_text.5569: Ought they not, as we just now admitted, to have become more just, instead of more unjust, under his management, if he who took charge of them was a good politician ?
tgt_text.5573: And are not the just gentle, as Homerz says ?
tgt_text.5579: However, he made them more savage than he re­ ceived them, and this against himself, which he would least of all have wished.
tgt_text.5581: Do you wish that I should agree with you ?
tgt_text.5583: If I seem to you to speak the truth.
tgt_text.5585: If, then, he made them more savage, he must have made them more unjust, and worse ?
tgt_text.5589: According to this reasoning, then, Pericles was not a good politician ?
tgt_text.5592: Socr. By Jupiter, nor as you say either, from what you have admitted.
tgt_text.5593: But, again, tell me with respect to Cimon.
tgt_text.5594: Did not they whom he took care of pass a sentence of ostra­ cism upon him, in order that they might not hear his voice for ten years ?
tgt_text.5595: And did they not do the very same to Themisto­ cles, and beside punish him with exile ?
tgt_text.5596: And did they not sentence Miltiades, the conqueror at Marathon, to be thrown into the Barathrum, and but for the Prytanis, would he not have been thrown into it ?
tgt_text.5597: These, however, if they had been good men, as you say, would never have suffered these things.
tgt_text.5598: 154. Good drivers, surely, do not at first keep themselves from falling from their cars, but, when they have trained their horses, and have themselves become better drivers, then fall off.
tgt_text.5599: This is never the case, either in driving, or in any.
tgt_text.5601: Does it appear so to you ?
tgt_text.5605: Our former statements, then, as it appears, are true, that we do not know any man who has been a good politician in this city.
tgt_text.5606: You admit that you know of none at present, but you say that formerly there were some, and you have selected these men:
tgt_text.5607: but these have appeared to be much the same as those of the present day, so that, if they were orators, they did not make use of the true rhetoric, for in that case they would not have fallen, nor yet did they employ flattery.
tgt_text.5609: However, Socrates, it is far from being the case, that any one of the present day will ever do such deeds as were done by any one of those.
tgt_text.5610: Socr. Neither, my excellent friend, do I blame these men, as servants of the city, but they appear to me to have been more efficient than those of the present day, and better able to procure for the city what it desired.
tgt_text.5611: But in changing and repressing their desires, by persuading and compelling them to such a course as would make the citizens become better, they scarcely differed at all from those of the present day;
tgt_text.5612: yet that is the only duty of a good citizen.
tgt_text.5613: But, with respect to providing ships, walls, and docks, and many other such things, I agree with you, that they were more able than the men of our day.
tgt_text.5614: 155. You and I, however, act ridiculously in our discussion.
tgt_text.5615: For during the whole time that we have been conversing we have not ceased to go round and round the same subject, and to misunderstand each what the other says.
tgt_text.5616: I think that you have often admitted and acknowledged that there is a twofold method of treatment, both with respect to the body and with respect to the soul:
tgt_text.5617: and that the one is ministerial, by which we are enabled to procure food, if our bodies are hungry, drink, if they are thirsty, and if they are cold, garments, coverlids, shoes, and all other things which the body stands in need of.
tgt_text.5618: And I purposely speak to you through these images, in order that you may understand me more easily.
tgt_text.5619: For when any one supplies these things, being either a retail tradesman or a merchant, or a manufac­ turer of any of them, a baker, a cook, a weaver, a shoemaker, or tanner, it is not at all surprising that such a person should appear, both to himself and others, to be concerned in the care of the body, that is, to all who are ignorant that, besides all these, there is a gymnastic and medicinal art, to which the care of the body really belongs, and whose duty it is to rule over all these arts, and to use their respective productions, through knowing what meats or drinks are good and bad for the health of the body, whereas all those others are igno­ rant of this ;
tgt_text.5620: for which reason all those other arts are servile, ministerial, and base, as regards the management of the body, but the gymnastic art and medicine are justly the mistresses of these.
tgt_text.5621: 156. That the case is the same with respect to the soul, you, at one time, appeared to me to have understood, and ad­ mitted it as if you knew what I meant;
tgt_text.5622: but shortly afterwards you went on to say that there have been good and upright men in this city, and when I asked you who they were, you appeared to me to adduce men very similar with respect to politics, as if, on my asking with respect to gymnastics, who have been or are good managers of the body, you had very seriously said to me, Thearion the baker, Mithæcus, who wrote on Sicilian cookery,, and Sarambus the tavern-keeper, and that they take wonderful care of the body, the first making admirable bread, the second, made-dishes, and the third, wine.
tgt_text.5623: Perhaps, then, you would be angry if I said to you, My friend, you know nothing about gymnastics ;
tgt_text.5624: you tell me of men who are minis­ ters and purveyors to desires, but who do not understand any thing great and good respecting them, and who, it may so hap­ pen, having filled men's bodies, and made them gross, and having been praised by them, end by ruining their old flesh.
tgt_text.5625: These men, on the other hand, through their ignorance, will not blame those who have pampered their appetites, as being the causes of their diseases, and of the loss of their old flesh, but they who may happen to have been with them, and to have given them some advice, when, after a long time, repletion, having been indulged in without any regard to health, comes bringing disease with it, these they will accuse and blame, and do them some mischief if they can, but those others, who are the causes of their maladies, they will extol.
tgt_text.5627: And now you, Callicles, act in very much the same way;
tgt_text.5628: you extol men who have pampered the Athenians by satiating their desires, and who they say have made the city great;
tgt_text.5629: and they do not perceive that it is swollen, and unsound through means of those ancient politicians :
tgt_text.5630: for, without considering temperance and justice, they have filled the city with harbours and docks, and walls and tributes, and such trifles.
tgt_text.5631: When, therefore, the crisis of their weakness comes, they will blame the advisers who are then present, but will extol Themistocles, Cimon, and Pericles, who were the causes of the mischief:
tgt_text.5632: and you perhaps, unless you are on your guard, and my friend Alcibiades, they will seize, when they have lost what they had before in ad­ dition to what they have acquired, although you are not the causes of the mischief, but perhaps accomplices.
tgt_text.5633: 158. More­ over, I both now see a very foolish thing happening, and I hear of it with respect to men of former times.
tgt_text.5634: For I perceive that when a city punishes any of its politicians as guilty of wrong, they are angry, and complain bitterly that they are treated shamefully;
tgt_text.5635: and having done the city many good services, they are then unjustly ruined by it, as they allege.
tgt_text.5636: But the whole is a falsehood.
tgt_text.5637: For no president of a city can ever be unjustly ruined by the very city over which he presides.
tgt_text.5638: For the case seems to be the same with such as profess themselves to be politicians, as it is with the sophists.
tgt_text.5639: For the sophists, though wise in other things, commit this absurdity;
tgt_text.5640: whereas they affirm that they are teachers of virtue, they often accuse their disciples of acting unjustly towards them, by defrauding them of their wages, and not making other requitals for the benefits they have received from them.
tgt_text.5641: But what can be more unreasonable than such language as this, that men who have become good and just, who have been freed from injustice by their teacher, and have acquired justice, should yet act unjustly from that very quality which they have not ?
tgt_text.5642: Does not this, my friend, appear to you to be absurd ?
tgt_text.5643: Of a truth, Callicles, you have compelled me to make a speech by your unwillingness to answer me.
tgt_text.5646: But should you not be able to speak unless some one answered you ?
tgt_text.5648: It seems as if I could:
tgt_text.5649: for now I have carried my dis­ course to a great length, seeing that you will not answer me.
tgt_text.5650: But my good friend, tell me, by Jupiter, the guardian of friendship, does it not appear to you unreasonable, that a man who says he has made another person good, should blame that person, because having been made good through his means, and being so, he has afterwards become bad ?
tgt_text.5654: Do you not, then, hear those speak in this manner w*ho profess to instruct men in virtue ?
tgt_text.5657: But what can you say of men of no worth ?
tgt_text.5659: What then can you say of those, who, while they pro­ fess to preside over the city, and to take care that it shall be as good as possible, then accuse it, when it so happens, as being very bad?
tgt_text.5660: Do you think that these differ at all from the former ?
tgt_text.5661: My good man, a sophist and an orator are the same thing, or nearly so, and very like, as I said to Polusa.
tgt_text.5662: But you, through ignorance, think that rhetoric is something exceedingly beautiful, and despise the other.
tgt_text.5663: But, in truth, the sophist's art is as much more beautiful than rhetoric, as the legislative is than the judicial, and the gymnastic art than medicine.
tgt_text.5665: But I for my part think that public speakers and sophists alone ought not to complain of the very thing that they teach, as being mischievous to themselves, or that in the very same charge they should at the same time accuse themselves for not having at all benefited those whom they profess to have benefited.
tgt_text.5670: And surely to impart a benefit without a stipulated reward, as is probable, is proper for these men only.
tgt_text.5671: if they assert what is true.
tgt_text.5672: For one who has received any other kind of benefit, as, for instance, who has acquired swiftness of foot through the instructions of a teacher of gymnastics, perhaps might deprive him of his gratuity, if the teacher of gymnastics had left it to him, without having made an agree­ ment for a fixed price, that he should be paid the money as nearly as possible at the same time that he imparted his skill to him.
tgt_text.5673: For men, I think, do not act unjustly through slow­ ness, but through injustice.
tgt_text.5678: If, therefore, any one should take away this, I mean injustice, there would be no danger of his ever being treated unjustly, but he alone might safely impart this benefit, if in truth he is able to make men good.
tgt_text.5684: For this reason then, as it appears, it is not at all disgraceful to take money for giving advice about other things, as, for instance, about architecture, or other arts.
tgt_text.5688: But with respect to this study, by what means a man may become as good as possible, and may best govern his own family or a city, it is reckoned disgraceful to withhold advice, except one should give him money.
tgt_text.5693: For it is evident that this is the reason that this alone of all benefits makes the person who has received it desirous of requiting it;
tgt_text.5694: so that it appears to be a good sign, if he who has imparted this benefit shall be recompensed in return;
tgt_text.5700: To which method, then, of taking care of the city do you advise me ?
tgt_text.5702: whether to that of thwarting the Athenians, in order that they may become as good as possible, as if I were a physician, or to that by which I should serve them, and curry favour with them.
tgt_text.5703: Tell me the truth, Cal­ licles.
tgt_text.5704: For, as you begun to speak freely to me, it is right you should continue to say what you think.
tgt_text.5705: And now speak well and nobly.
tgt_text.5707: I say, then, that I advise you to serve them.
tgt_text.5708: 162. Socr. You advise me, therefore, most noble Sir, to employ flattery.
tgt_text.5710: Unless you prefer calling him a Mysianb, Socrates;
tgt_text.5711: for if you will do so-Socr.
tgt_text.5712: Do not repeat what you have often said, that any one who pleases will kill me, lest I too should say again, that a bad man would slay a good one;
tgt_text.5713: nor that he will take away my property, if I have any, lest I too should say again, that after he has taken it away he will not be able to make any use of it, but as he has unjustly taken it from me, so having got it, he will make an unjust use of it;
tgt_text.5717: How confident you seem to me to be, Socrates, that you will never suffer any of these things, as being one who lives out of harm's way, and who can never be brought before a court of justice by a man, perhaps, utterly depraved and vile !
tgt_text.5719: I should indeed be foolish, Callicles, if I did not think that any one in this city might suffer any thing that might happen.
tgt_text.5720: This however I well know, that if I should go before a court of justice, and be exposed to any of the dangers you mention, he who takes me thither will be a bad man.
tgt_text.5721: For no good man would accuse one who has not com­ mitted injustice.
tgt_text.5722: And it would not be at all wonderful, if I should be condemned to death.
tgt_text.5723: Do you wish I should tell you why I expect this ?
tgt_text.5728: I think that I, in conjunction with a few Athe­ nians, (that I may not say alone,) apply myself to the true political art, and alone of those of the present day perform the duties of a citizen.
tgt_text.5729: Since, then, in the conversations which I enter into from time to time, I do not speak for the purpose of conciliating popular favour, but with a view to that which is best, and not to that which is most agreeable, and as I am not willing to do those fine things that you advise, I shall not have any thing to say in a court of justice.
tgt_text.5730: And the same illustration occurs to me that I mentioned to Polus.
tgt_text.5731: For I should be judged as a physician would be judged by children, with a cook for his accuser.
tgt_text.5732: For consider what defence such a man would make when taken before them, if one should accuse him as follows :
tgt_text.5733: ' 0 boys, this man has done you a great deal of mischief, and destroys both you and even the youngest of you, for, by cutting, cauterizing, weakening and choking you, he reduces you to great straits, giving you the bitterest draughts, and compelling you to hunger and thirst;
tgt_text.5734: not as I do who feed you with many sweet and various dainties.'
tgt_text.5735: What do you think a physician when brought to such an extremity would have to say ?
tgt_text.5736: If he should say the truth, ‘ I did all these things, boys, for your health,' what a clamour do you think such judges would raise against him ?
tgt_text.5740: one must think so, at least.
tgt_text.5742: Do you not think, then, that he would be alto­ ,-ether at a loss what to say ?
tgt_text.5746: And I know that I should be treated just in the same way, if I came before a court of justice.
tgt_text.5747: For I should not be able to mention any pleasures which I had procured for them, which they consider as benefits and advantages;
tgt_text.5748: but I neither envy those who procure them, nor those for whom they are procured.
tgt_text.5749: And if any one should- say that I corrupt younger men, by causing them to doubt, or that I revile the elder men, by speaking bitter words, either privately or publicly, I should not be able to say the truth, that " I say and do all these things justly, and for your advantage, judges, and nothing else."
tgt_text.5750: So that I should probably suffer whatever might happen.
tgt_text.5752: Does a man, then, appear to you, Socrates, to be well off in a city who is thus circumstanced, and is unable to help himself?
tgt_text.5755: If there is that in him, Callicles, which you have often allowed, namely, if he can assist himself, by neither hav­ ing said or done any thing unjust towards men or towards gods.
tgt_text.5756: For this aid has often been acknowledged by us to be the best that a man can have for himself.

tgt_text.5858: IN this dialogue Socrates relates to a friend, whose name is not given, a discussion which he had just had with Pro­ tagoras the sophist, of Abdera.
tgt_text.5859: Hippocrates, a young Athenian, had roused Socrates very early in the morning and entreated him to accompany him on a visit to Protagoras, who was then at Athens staying at the house of Callias, and whose pupil he was anxious to be­ come.
tgt_text.5860: On arriving there, they find the sophist attended by a crowd of admirers, and moreover Hippias of Elis and Pro­ dicus of Ceos, surrounded by their respective followers a.

tgt_text.5862: When all are seated, Socrates repeats to Protagoras, that Hippocrates is desirous of becoming his pupil, and wishes to know what advantage he may expect to derive from associating with him.
tgt_text.5863: Pro­ tagoras tells him that from the very first day of their inter­ course he will become a better man than he was before, and will daily make further progress.

tgt_text.5868: To this end Protagoras relates a fable in which he explains how the capacity of becoming virtuous was imparted by Jupiter to mankind;
tgt_text.5869: and then argues that as men are punished for in­ justice, impiety, and the like, it follows that they must think that these virtues ought to be possessed and may be acquired by all men, for that they would not punish them for a mere defect of mind any more than of body, if it were natural and not attributable to the fault of the individualc.
tgt_text.5870: Socrates having complimented him on his eloquence, ac­ cording to his usual method, begs that he will answer his questions briefly;

tgt_text.5872: He therefore wishes to know whether virtue is one thing, and justice, tem­ perance and holiness, parts of it, or whether they are all names of one and the same thing.

tgt_text.6091: For my part, I say that the art of a sophist is ancient, but the men who professed it in ancient times, fearing the odium attached to it, sought to conceal it, and veiled it over, some under the garb of poetry, as Homer, Hesiod, and Simonides, and others under that of the mysteries and prophecies, such as Orpheus and Musseus, and their followers, and some I perceive have veiled it under the gymnastic art, as Iccus of Tarentum, and one of the present day who is a sophist, inferior to none, He­ rodicus of Selymbria, who was originally of Megara.

tgt_text.6158: There was once a time, when gods were, but mortal races were not.

tgt_text.6186: When, therefore, man had become partaker of a divine condition, first of all through this relationship to deity, he alone of all animals acknowledged gods, and set about building altars and statues of gods :

tgt_text.6206: "Thus, then, Socrates, and for these reasons, as well others as the Athenians, when a question arises about excel­ lence in building, or any other mechanical art, think that few only should give their advice;

tgt_text.6209: but when they proceed to a consultation respecting political excellence, which ought to depend entirely on justice and temperance, they very properly allow every man to speak, because it is the duty of every one to partake of this excellence, otherwise there can be no cities.
tgt_text.6211: Socrates, is the cause of this fact.
tgt_text.6212: 37. "And that you may not think that you are deceived, when you are told that in reality all men are of opinion that every one partakes of justice, and of the other political excel­ lences, take this additional proof.
tgt_text.6213: For in other kinds of ex­ cellence, as you say, if any one asserts that he is a good flute- player, or skilled in any other art, of which he is ignorant, they either ridicule him, or are indignant, and his friends go to him and admonish him as a madman;
tgt_text.6214: but in justice and other political virtues, even though they know of any man that he is unjust, yet if he himself tells the truth of himself in the presence of many persons, what in the other case they con­ sidered prudence, to speak the truth, in this case they consider madness;
tgt_text.6215: and they say that all men ought to say they are just, whether they are so or not, or that he is mad who does not lay claim to justice, because it is necessary that every one should, in some respect, partake of it, or no longer be a man.38.
tgt_text.6216: "I say these things to shew that they very properly per­ mit every man to give advice concerning this virtue, because they think that every one partakes of it.
tgt_text.6217: But that men think that it exists not naturally or spontaneously, but that it is taught and acquired by study, by whomsoever it is acquired, this I will in the next place endeavour to shew.
tgt_text.6218: For whatever evils men think others respectively have by nature or fortune no one is angry with, nor admonishes, or teaches, or punishes the possessors of them, in order to make them otherwise than they are, but pity them.
tgt_text.6219: For instance, who would be so fool­ ish as to attempt to do any of these things to the deformed, or the little, or the weak ?
tgt_text.6220: For they know, I think, that these things, such as are beautiful and the contraries, happen to men by nature and fortune :
tgt_text.6221: but such advantages as they think re­ sult to men from study, practice, and instruction, if any one does not possess them but their contrary evils, for these things anger, and punishment, and admonition, are had recourse to :
tgt_text.6222: of these one is injustice, and so is impiety, and in short, every thing that is contrary to political virtue.
tgt_text.6223: Here, then, every man is angry with and admonishes every other, clearly because he thinks it may be acquired by study and instruction.
tgt_text.6224: 39. For if you will consider, Socrates, of what avail it is to punish those who act unjustly, this very thing will teach you that men think virtue is to be acquired.
tgt_text.6225: For no one punishes those who act unjustly, merely attending to this and for this reason, that any one has so acted, unless it be one who like a brute avenges himself irrationally;

tgt_text.6227: And he who entertains such a thought must think that virtue may be taught;

tgt_text.6229: 40 All, therefore, have this opinion who inflict punish­ ment, either privately or publicly.
tgt_text.6230: Now all other men, and especially the Athenians, your fellow-citizens, inflict punishment on and correct those who they think act unjustly;
tgt_text.6231: so that, ac­ cording to this reasoning, the Athenians also are among the number of those who think that virtue may be acquired and taught.

tgt_text.7073: PHÆDRUS, whom we have already3 met with among the fol­ lowers of the sophist Hippias, happening to meet with Socrates, tells him that he has just left the orator Lysias, who had writ­ ten and recited a speech on the subject of love, in which he argued that a youth ought rather to shew favour to one who is not in love than to one who is.
tgt_text.7074: Socrates, who pretends to be very anxious to hear the speech, begs Phaedrus to repeat it from memory as well as he is able, for he cannot doubt but that he has learnt it by heart, so great is his admiration for its author.
tgt_text.7075: Phaedrus affects shyness, though in reality desirous of practising himself on Socrates:
tgt_text.7076: at length, however, Socrates discovers that he has a copy of it under his cloak, so they pro­ ceed on their walk, talking by the way, till they reach a plane- tree on the banks of the Ilissus, outside the walls of Athens, under whose ample shade they lie downb.
tgt_text.7077: Phædrus reads the speech, which in addition to the faults of obscurity, inconclusiveness, and tautology, takes a very low and sensual view of the passion of love c.
tgt_text.7078: When it is ended, Phædrus asks Socrates what he thinks of it, and whether it is not a wonderful composition, especially as to the language.
tgt_text.7079: Socrates at first praises it ironically, but on being pressed by Phædrus points out some of its faults, and says that even Lysias himself could not be satisfied with it, and that many others have both spoken and written finer things on the same subject, with which at that very instant his breast is full.
tgt_text.7080: Phæ­ drus catches at this, and insists on Socrates repeating these fine things, promising that if he says any thing that excels the speech of Lysias he will erect his statue in gold in Olympiad.
tgt_text.7081: As it is the present design of Socrates to take the same low view of love that Lysias had done, he determines to speak with his face covered, that he may not falter through shame.
tgt_text.7082: He begins by a definition of love, which he represents to be desire hurried on to the pleasure derived from personal beauty;
tgt_text.7083: and then he goes on to shew, with great perspicuity, how a person under the influence of such a passion must needs be anxious that the beloved object should not excel himself or be admired by others.
tgt_text.7084: Then with regard to the body, he will wish to make it effeminate, and be anxious that his beloved should be as much as possible dependent on him;
tgt_text.7085: and at length he will become unfaithful, forget all his former vows and promises, and leave his favourite despised and destitute, who will suffer most of all in this, that he has been debarred from cultivating his soul, than which, he adds, there neither is nor ever will be any thing more precious in the sight of gods and men e.Phædrus expects that Socrates will not only shew the dis­ advantages of granting favours to a lover, but also go on to point out the advantages of granting them to one who is not in love.
tgt_text.7086: This, however, he refuses to do;
tgt_text.7087: and then, conscience- stricken for that he has been guilty of an offence against the deity of Love in speaking of him in so impious a manner, he determines on making his recantation, by uttering a speech which shall describe that deity in his true character.
tgt_text.7088: He be­ gins by condemning his former assertion that favour ought rather to be shewn to one who is not in love than to a lover, be­ cause the latter is mad and the former in his sober senses.
tgt_text.7089: For, he argues, it is not universally true that madness is an evil, so far from it, that the greatest blessings spring from madness, for even prophetic inspiration is a species of madness and de­ rives its very name from it.
tgt_text.7090: And love is one of many kinds of madness, and as such the source of the greatest happiness to man.
tgt_text.7091: To prove this, he says, it is necessary to examine into the nature of the soul, both human and divine.
tgt_text.7092: The soul, then, is immortal, because it contains the principle of motion within itself (a subtle argument which it may be observed was not adduced in the Phædo, where the soul's immortality was the immediate point under discussion.)
tgt_text.7093: Still, to explain what the soul is would require a divine and lengthened exposition ;
tgt_text.7094: he must therefore content himself with saying what it is like.
tgt_text.7095: He therefore compares the soul to a pair of winged steeds and a charioteer.
tgt_text.7096: The horses and charioteers of the gods are all good, but all others are mixed.
tgt_text.7097: While the soul is perfect and winged it soars aloft, but when it loses its wings it is borne downward and becomes united with a body in which it takes up its abode, and the two united are called mortal.
tgt_text.7098: He then describes how Jupiter goes first, driving a winged chariot, and is followed by a host of gods and demons distributed into eleven divisions :
tgt_text.7099: in their flight they reach the external regions of heaven, and behold truth, justice, temperance, science, in their essences.
tgt_text.7100: Other inferior souls endeavour to follow and imitate them;
tgt_text.7102: those that get a glimpse of any of the true essences are free from harm till the next revolution, but those that are unable to do so are weighed down and lose their wings, and become implanted in earthly natures of various orders, and then, according to their conduct in this condition, are either restored to their former state or still further degraded.
tgt_text.7103: The mind of the philosopher, however, is alone furnished with wings, because his memory dwells on that which is divined
tgt_text.7104: This then is the madness above spoken of, when one, behold­ ing beauty in this lower world, is reminded of the true, and looking upwards to it despises things below and is deemed to be affected with madness.
tgt_text.7105: But he who has become corrupted is not easily carried hence to beauty itself, nor does he reve­ rence it when he beholds it, but looks upon it with carnal sensuality;
tgt_text.7106: whereas he, who has not been so far corrupted, when he beholds the imitation of beauty here, reverences it as a god, and, but for the imputation of madness, would sacrifice to it.
tgt_text.7107: Then his wings begin to swell again and en­ deavour to burst forth anew;
tgt_text.7108: but when separated from the beautiful object the soul becomes parched and the passages through which the wings shoot forth become closed.
tgt_text.7109: Thus alternately tormented with agony and joy, it becomes frantic and runs about trying to see the possessor of the beauty.
tgt_text.7111: Now when a follower of Jupiter is thus seized, he is better able to bear the burden of the winged god:
tgt_text.7112: for such a one seeks one who resembles Jupiter to be the object of his love;
tgt_text.7113: and when he has found him, he en­ deavours to make him like his own gods.
tgt_text.7114: As each soul was before divided into three parts, two having the form of horses, and the third that of a charioteer, so that division must still be maintained.
tgt_text.7115: When therefore the cha­ rioteer beholds the love-inspiring sight, the obedient horse is easily restrained, but the other compels them to hurry to the favourite, and longs to indulge in the delights of love.
tgt_text.7116: But the charioteer, on approaching him, is carried back to absolute beauty, and being awe-struck falls backward and throws the horses on their haunches.
tgt_text.7117: When by being repeatedly checked in this way the vicious horse has laid aside his insolence, he becomes humbled and the soul of the lover follows his favourite with reverence and awe.
tgt_text.7118: And the beloved being worshipped by one who does not feign the passion but who really feels it, re­ quites the affection of his worshipper, and in turn longs for the lover in the same manner that he is longed for, possessing love's image;
tgt_text.7120: If then the better parts of their mind prevail so as to lead to a well-regulated life and philo­ sophy, they pass their life in bliss and concord, and when they depart this life, they become winged and win one of the three truly Olympic contests, a greater good than which neither human prudence nor divine madness can bestow on man.
tgt_text.7121: If however, they have adopted a coarser and less philosophic mode of life, but still honourable, in the end they find the body without wings indeed, yet making an effort to become winged and so carry off no trifling prize of impassioned madness h.

tgt_text.7126: The first essential is that the speaker should know the truth of the subject on which he is about to speak.
tgt_text.7127: And though it is commonly said that an orator need not know what is really just, but only what will appear so to the multitude, yet Socrates with great force destroys this fallacy, and shews that such rhetoric is not an art but an inartistic trick;
tgt_text.7128: for a genuine art of speaking neither does nor can exist without laying hold of truth.
tgt_text.7129: Rhetoric must be an art that leads the soul by means of argument.
tgt_text.7130: Now in courts of justice and popular assemblies men succeed by making things appear similar to each other so far as they are capable of being made appear so;
tgt_text.7131: and deception will more frequently occur in things that nearly resemble each other, so that a person who means to persuade or deceive another must be able to distinguish ac­ curately the similarity and dissimilarity of things, and so lead his hearer by means of resemblances.
tgt_text.7132: Taking this as his principle, Socrates proceeds to shew that the speech of Lysias is altogether inartistic, for that he ought first of all to have defined Love and divided it into its different species and shewn of which class he was going to speak, whereas he begins where he should have ended, and throughout speaks at random with­ out any definite design.
tgt_text.7133: He then proceeds to comment on his own two speeches.
tgt_text.7134: In one he argued that favour ought to be shewn to one that is in love, in the other to a person that is not in love.
tgt_text.7135: In one he said that love was a kind of divine madness, and then dividing this madness into four parts he shewed that the madness of Love is the best.
tgt_text.7136: In these speeches, then, are seen the two methods of arguing correctly, definition and division, the former of which contemplates many things under one aspect and brings them together under one general idea, the latter separates that general idea into speciesk.
tgt_text.7137: Socrates then ridicules the rules of rhetoric laid down by many of the sophists, and having passed a high eulogium on Pericles, shews that a perfect orator must know the real nature of the things to which he will have to apply his speeches, and that is the soul;
tgt_text.7138: for as the power of speech consists in leading the soul, he must know how many kinds of soul there are, and by what arguments each kind is most easily persuaded1.
tgt_text.7139: From speaking he proceeds to writing, and tells a pleasant story of the invention of letters, and remarks that the evil of writing is, that, like painting, if you ask it a question it cannot answer;
tgt_text.7140: and when once written it is tossed from hand to hand, as well among those who understand it as those who do not.
tgt_text.7141: But there is another kind of discourse far more excellent, which is written in the learner's mind, and knows when to speak and when to be silent.
tgt_text.7142: The conclusion of the whole is that a speaker should be acquainted with the true nature of each subject on which he speaks or writes, be able to define, and divide things into their species until he reaches the indivisible, and to inves­ tigate the nature of the soul and apply his discourses to each soul according to its capacity.
tgt_text.7143: Then, with a message, in accordance with these principles, to Lysias, and a high encomium on Isocrates, who promised to be led by a diviner impulse to holier and higher things, he con­ cludes by praying that Pan would grant him to be beautiful in the inner man, and that all outward things might be at peace with those within.

tgt_text.7751: As in the beginning of this account I divided each soul into three parts, two of them having the form of horses, and the third that of a charioteer, so let us still maintain that division:

tgt_text.7754: That one of them, then, which is in the nobler condition, is in form erect, finely-moulded, high-necked, hook-nosed, white- coloured, black-eyed, a lover of honour, with temperance and modesty, and a companion of true glory, without the whip is driven by word of command and voice only:
tgt_text.7755: the other, on the other hand, is crooked, thick set, clumsily put together, strong- necked, short-throated, flat-faced, black-coloured, gray-eyed, hot-blooded, a companion of insolence and swaggering, shaggy about the ears, deaf, scarcely obedient to whip and spur toge­ ther.

tgt_text.8575: Thus, with re­ spect to colour, it does not actually exist, it is neither in the 1 object seen nor in the eye itself, but results from the applica­ tion of the eye to the object, and so is the intermediate pro­ duction of both.
tgt_text.8576: Again if you compare six with four they ap­ pear to be half as many again, but if with twelve, only the half, whence it appears that the same number is at one time great, at another small, which would not be the case if numbers had a fixed and determined magnitude.
tgt_text.8577: The principle then on which all things depend is this,
tgt_text.8578: That the universe is nothing but motion, of which there are two species, the one active, the other passive, by the union of which that which is per­ ceivable and perception itself consist.
tgt_text.8579: Thus when the eye and a corresponding object, meeting together, produce white­ ness and its connate perception, the eye sees, and becomes not vision, but a seeing eye, and the object itself becomes not whiteness but white:
tgt_text.8580: so that nothing is essentially one, but is always being produced by something else, and therefore the word "being" must be entirely done away with.
tgt_text.8581: But here it may be objected that the perceptions produced in persons who dream, or are diseased or mad, are utterly false, and so far are the things that appear to them from existing, that none of them have any real existence at all;
tgt_text.8582: how then can it be said that perception is science, and that things which appear to every one are to that person what they appear to be ?
tgt_text.8583: The answer is, that the things which appear are most certainly true to the percipient;
tgt_text.8584: just as if wine appears bitter to a sick person, to him it is certainly bitter;
tgt_text.8585: and again with re­ gard to dreams, there is no certain way of distinguishing a state of being awake from dreaming;
tgt_text.8586: and as the object per­ ceived and the percipient exist or are produced by relation to each other, neither exists or is produced of itself, but the ob­ ject perceived does exist in relation to the percipient and to him is true, so that he has a scientific knowledge of what he perceives bSocrates then proposes to examine the correctness of Prota­ goras's theory.

tgt_text.8589: Well then, when we hear barbarians speak, whose language we have not learnt, are we to say that we both hear and know what they say ?

tgt_text.8593: But Protagoras will not admit this conclusion, but will say that memory is very different from perception, and that the things which we appear to remember are not the same as those that we formerly perceived.

tgt_text.8614: This part of the argument being brought to a close, Socrates next proposes to consider the essence that is said to consist in motion, a doctrine which the followers of Heraclitus were then advocating very strenuously.
tgt_text.8615: Now there are two species of motion, removal and change;

tgt_text.8617: and all things must undergo both kinds of motion, other­ wise the same thing would be both in motion and at rest at the same time, and in that case it would not be more correct to say that all things are in motion than that they are at rest.
tgt_text.8618: Since then every thing must be continually undergoing a pro­ cess of change at the same time that it is in motion, there can be nothing fixed and certain, so that perception cannot be science, for, as all things are in motion, perception itself, which results from the relation between the object and the percipient, must be in a constant state of motion and change g.
tgt_text.8619: Thesetetus now resumes the argument, and though it would seem that Protagoras's doctrine had been already sufficiently refuted, yet Socrates resolves to try it by one more test.

tgt_text.8624: The first definition of science attempted by Theætetus being thus overthrown, Socrates again asks him, What science is.

tgt_text.8627: People, he says, must either know or not know things about which they form judgments.
tgt_text.8628: Now false judgments are formed, when a person thinks that things which he does not know are certain other things that he does not know, or when he thinks that things which he does know are other things that he does know, or that things which he does not know are things that he does know.

tgt_text.8636: Suppose that we have in our souls a waxen tablet of various qualities in different persons :

tgt_text.10557: If, therefore, to speak to one's-selfis to form judgments, no one, who speaks and forms judgments of both objects, and touches upon both with his soul, would say and judge that one is another.
tgt_text.10558: You must therefore give up what you said about the other.
tgt_text.10559: For I assert this, that no one thinks that the ugly is beautiful, or any thing else of the kind.
tgt_text.10561: I give it up then, Socrates, and it appears to me as you say.
tgt_text.10563: It is impossible, then, for one who forms judgments about both, to think that the one is the other.
tgt_text.10568: He, however, who judges one thing only, but the other in no respect, will never judge that the one is the other.
tgt_text.10571: for he would be compelled to touch upon that also of which he does not judge.
tgt_text.10573: It is not possible then for a person who judges either both or one of the two, to judge that one is the other:
tgt_text.10574: so that if any one should define false judgment to be the judgment of one thing instead of another, he would say nothing to the pur­ pose ;
tgt_text.10575: for neither in this way, nor in those before mentioned, does it appear that false judgment pertains to us.
tgt_text.10579: However, Theætetus, if this should appear not to be so, we shall be compelled to admit many absurdities.
tgt_text.10583: I will not tell you, until I have endeavoured to con­ sider the matter in every point of view;
tgt_text.10584: for I should be ashamed for both of us, if, while we are in the difficulty we are, we should be compelled to admit what I now say.
tgt_text.10585: But if we discover the object of our search and become free, then we will speak of others, as subject to this, being ourselves placed beyond the reach of ridicule:
tgt_text.10586: but if we shall continue still in­ volved in difficulties, we must humble ourselves, I imagine, and give ourselves up to discussion, like those who are sea­ sick, to be trampled on and treated as it pleases.
tgt_text.10587: Hear, then, how I still find a way out of our enquiry.
tgt_text.10592: I shall deny that we made a correct admission, when we admitted that it is impossible for a person to judge that what he knows is what he does not know and be thus de­ ceived ;
tgt_text.10593: but in some respect it is possible.
tgt_text.10595: Do you mean that which I suspected at the time when we said this, might be the case, that sometimes I know­ ing Socrates, and seeing another person at a distance whom I do not know, have thought it was Socrates, whom I do know ?
tgt_text.10596: For what you mention happens in a case of this kind.
tgt_text.10598: Are we not, then, driven from that position, because it made us, while we know, not know the things that we do know ?
tgt_text.10602: Let us not, then, make our assumption in this way but as follows;
tgt_text.10603: and perhaps it will in some respect succeed for us, and perhaps it will oppose us.
tgt_text.10604: For we are in a condition in which it is necessary to examine our whole argument in every point of view.
tgt_text.10605: Consider, therefore, whether I say any thing to the purpose.
tgt_text.10606: Is it possible for a person who did not know something before, afterwards to learn it ?
tgt_text.10610: And can he not also learn another thing after another ?
tgt_text.10614: Suppose, then, I beg, for the sake of argument, that we have in our souls a waxen tablet, in one larger, in an­ other smaller, in one of purer wax, in another of impurer, in some of harder, and in others again of softer, but in some of a moderate quality.
tgt_text.10618: Let us say, then, that this is a gift of Mnemosyne the mother of the Muses ;
tgt_text.10619: and that, whatever we wish to remember of things that we have seen, or heard, or have ourselves thought of, we impress in this, by placing it under our perceptions and thoughts, as if we were taking off the impressions from rings:
tgt_text.10620: and that whatever is imprinted, this we remember and know, as long as its image remains;
tgt_text.10621: but when it is effaced, or can be no longer imprinted, we forget and do not know it.
tgt_text.10625: When, therefore, a person knows these things and considers any of the things that he sees or hears, consider whether in this way he can judge falsely ?
tgt_text.10629: By thinking with respect to what he knows, that they i are at one time the things that he knows, and at another the things that he does not know.
tgt_text.10630: For in a former part of our discussion we made an improper admission in admitting that this was impossible.
tgt_text.10633: But how do you mean now ?
tgt_text.10635: We must speak thus on this subject, defining it from the beginning:
tgt_text.10636: It is impossible that he who knows any thing, and has a remembrance of it in his soul, but does not actually perceive it, can think that it is some other thing that he knows, of which he has the impression, though he does not perceive it:
tgt_text.10637: and again, it is impossible that any one can think that what he knows is that which he does not know, and of which he has not the seal:
tgt_text.10638: or that what he does not know is that which he does not know:
tgt_text.10639: or that what he does not know is that which he does know:
tgt_text.10640: or think that what he perceives is some other thing that he perceives:
tgt_text.10641: or that what he perceives is something that he does not perceive :
tgt_text.10642: or that what he does not perceive is some other thing that he does not perceive :
tgt_text.10643: or that what he does not perceive is something that he docs perceive.
tgt_text.10644: And again it is still more impossible, if that can be, that a person should think that what he knows and perceives, and of which he has an impression by means of perception, is some­ thing else that he knows and perceives, and of which in like manner he has an impression by means of perception.
tgt_text.10645: And it is impossible that what he knows and perceives, and of which he has a correct remembrance, he can think is something else that he knows :
tgt_text.10646: or that what he knows and perceives, and in like manner retains in his remembrance, is something else that he perceives:
tgt_text.10647: or again, that what he neither knows nor per­ ceives is something else that he neither knows nor perceives:
tgt_text.10648: or that what he neither knows nor perceives is something else that he does not know;
tgt_text.10649: or that what he neither knows nor perceives is something else that he does not perceive.
tgt_text.10650: In all these cases it is utterly impossible for any one to judge falsely.
tgt_text.10651: It remains, therefore, that it must take place, if anywhere, in the following cases.
tgt_text.10655: perhaps I shall understand you better from them ;
tgt_text.10656: for at present I do not follow you.
tgt_text.10658: In things which a person knows, he may think that they are different from the things that he knows and perceives;
tgt_text.10659: or from those which he does not know, but perceives;
tgt_text.10660: or that the things which he knows and perceives are some of the things which he likewise knows and perceives.
tgt_text.10662: Now I am left much further behind than I was.
tgt_text.10663: Socr. Listen again, then, as follows:
tgt_text.10664: I, knowing Theodorus, and remembering within myself what kind of a person he is, and in like manner, Theaetetus, do I not sometimes see them, and sometimes not, and sometimes touch them, and sometimes not, and hear or perceive them by some other sense, but some­ times have I no perception of you at all, yet nevertheless do I remember you, and know you within myself?
tgt_text.10668: Understand this, then, the first of the things that I wish to prove, that it is possible for a man not to perceive what he knows, and that it is possible for him to perceive it.
tgt_text.10672: And does it not often happen that a man does not per­ ceive what he does not know, and often that he perceives it only?
tgt_text.10676: Consider then, whether you can now follow me better.
tgt_text.10677: Socrates knows Theodorus and Thesetetus, but he sees neither of them, nor has he any other perception respecting them, now he can never form this judgment within himself, that Theæ­ tetus is Theodorus?
tgt_text.10678: Do I say any thing to the purpose or not ?
tgt_text.10682: This then was the first of the cases that I mentioned.
tgt_text.10686: But the second was this, that I knowing one of you, but not knowing the other, and perceiving neither, should never think that he whom I know is the person whom I do not know.
tgt_text.10690: The third was this, that I neither knowing nor per­ ceiving either of them, should not think that he whom I do' not know is some other person of those whom I do not know:
tgt_text.10691: and consider that you again hear in succession all the instances before put, in which I shall never form a false judgment re­ specting you and Theodorus, neither while knowing nor igno­ rant of you both, nor while knowing one, and not the other;
tgt_text.10692: and in the same way with regard to perceptions, if you follow me.
tgt_text.10697: It remains, therefore, that I may form a false judg­ ment in this case, when knowing you and Theodorus, and hav­ ing the impression of both of you in that waxen tablet made by a seal ring as it were, seeing you both from a distance and not sufficiently distinguishing you, I endeavour, by attributing the peculiar impression of each to his peculiar aspect, applying it so as to adapt it to its own form in order that I may recognise it, then failing in this, and changing them like those that put their shoes on the wrong feet, I fit the aspect of each to the impression of the other, as happens in looking into mirrors, where the sight passes from the right to the left, so I fall into the same error;
tgt_text.10698: then mistaken opinion and false judgment take place.
tgt_text.10700: What happens with regard to judgment, Socrates, seems wonderfully like what you describe.
tgt_text.10702: Still further, when, knowing both of you, in addition to knowing I perceive one, but not the other, I have a know- ledge of the other not according to perception, which I thus described before, but you did not then understand me.
tgt_text.10707: I said this however, that a person who knows and perceives one and has a knowledge of him according to perception, will never think that he is some other person whom he knows and perceives, and of whom he has a know­ ledge according to perception.
tgt_text.10708: Was not this what I said?
tgt_text.10712: There remained then the case that was just now mentioned, in which we said that false judgment takes place, when a person knowing you both and seeing you both, or having some other perception of you both, has not the im­ pression of each according to the perception of each, but, like an unskilful archer, shoots beside the mark and misses, this then is called a falsehood.
tgt_text.10716: When, therefore, perception is present to one of the impressions, and not to the other, and the one applies the im­ pression of the absent perception to that which is present, in this case the mind is 'altogether deceived:
tgt_text.10717: and, in a word, with respect to things that a person has neither known nor ever per­ ceived, it is not possible, as it seems, either to be deceived, or to form a false judgment, if there is any soundness in what we now say:
tgt_text.10718: but with respect to things that we know and perceive, in these very things judgment is conversant and turns round, becoming both false and true, by collecting together in a direct and straight line the copies and marks proper to each, it is true, but sideways and obliquely, false.
tgt_text.10721: Is it not well described, Socrates ?
tgt_text.10723: You will say so still more, when you hear what follows.
tgt_text.10724: For to judge truly is beautiful, but to be deceived is base.
tgt_text.10728: They say, then, that these things proceed from hence.
tgt_text.10729: When the wax in any one's soul is deep, abundant, smooth, and properly moulded, objects entering by means of the percep­ tions and impressing themselves on this heart r of the soul, as Homer calls it, obscurely intimating its resemblance to wax, then pure and sufficiently deep impressions being made in these, become lasting, and such men are.
tgt_text.10730: first of all easily taught, next have retentive memories, and lastly do not change the impressions of the perceptions, but form true judgments;
tgt_text.10731: for, as these impressions are clear, and in a wide space, they quickly distribute to their proper images each of the things that are called beings.;
tgt_text.10732: and such men are called wise.
tgt_text.10733: Does it not appear so to you ?
tgt_text.10737: When, therefore, any one's heart is covered with hair, which the very wise poet has celebrated, or when it is muddy, and not of pure wax, or very soft, or hard, those in whom it is soft are easily taught, but are forgetful, and those in whom it is hard, the contrary;
tgt_text.10738: but those who have it hairy and rough, and stony or full of earth or mixed mud, have indistinct im­ pressions ;
tgt_text.10739: they are also indistinct in those that are hard, for there is no depth in them;
tgt_text.10740: they are likewise indistinct in those that are soft, for by being confused they soon become obscure ;
tgt_text.10741: but if, in addition to all this, they fall one upon another by reason of narrowness of space, if any one's soul is little, they are still more indistinct than the others.
tgt_text.10742: All these, therefore, are such as form false judgments.
tgt_text.10743: For when they see, or hear, or think about any thing, not being able at once to attribute each object to its impression, they are slow, and attributing different objects to different impressions, they for the most part see wrongly, and hear wrongly, and think wrongly;
tgt_text.10744: and these are said to be deceived in objects and ignorant.
tgt_text.10746: You speak as correctly as man can do, Socrates.
tgt_text.10749: Shall we say, then, that there are false judg­ ments in us ?
tgt_text.10757: Do we, then, consider it to have been sufficiently established that these two judgments do without doubt exist ?
tgt_text.10761: A talkative man, Theætetus, appears to be really troublesome and disagreeable.
tgt_text.10766: Because I am angry at my own ignorance, and, in truth, talkativeness.
tgt_text.10767: For what other name can any one give it when a man drags the conversation upwards and downwards, and cannot be persuaded through his dulness, and is with diffi­ culty torn from each several topic ?
tgt_text.10771: I am not only angry, but I am afraid that I should not know what to answer, if any one should ask me, " Socrates, have you found that false judgment is neither in the percep­ tions compared with each other, nor in the thoughts, but in the conjunction of perception with thought ?"
tgt_text.10772: I think I shall say, I have, priding myself as if we had made a very fine dis­ covery.
tgt_text.10775: What has just now been proved appears to me, Socrates, to be by no means despicable.
tgt_text.10777: Do you therefore assert, he will say, that we can never suppose that a man whom we think of only, but do not see, is a horse, which we neither see nor touch, but think of only;
tgt_text.10778: and do not perceive in any other way ?
tgt_text.10779: I believe I should say, that I do assert this.
tgt_text.10784: he will say, according to this mode of reasoning, can the number eleven, which one thinks of only, ever be supposed to be twelve, which also one thinks of only ?
tgt_text.10787: I should answer, that a person seeing or touching might suppose that eleven are twelve, but that he would never think thus respecting numbers which he embraces only in thought.

tgt_text.10793: No, by Jupiter, but many suppose that they are eleven.
tgt_text.10794: And if a person considers about a greater number, he is still more mistaken;
tgt_text.10795: for I suppose that you rather speak about every number.
tgt_text.10797: You suppose rightly, but consider whether any thing else ever happens than this, that he supposes that the number twelve impressed in his soul is eleven ?
tgt_text.10801: Does it not then come back to our former statements ?
tgt_text.10802: For he who is in this condition supposes that what he knows is something else that he also knows, which we said was impos­ sible, and from which very circumstance we demonstrated that there is no such thing as false judgment, in order that the same person might not be compelled to know and not to know the same thing at the same time.
tgt_text.10806: Therefore we must shew that false judgment is some­ thing else than an interchange of mind with perception.
tgt_text.10807: For, if this were so, we could never be deceived in the thoughts themselves:
tgt_text.10808: but now there is either no such thing as false judgment, or it is possible for a person not to know what he knows :
tgt_text.10809: and which of these two do you choose ?
tgt_text.10811: You offer me a difficult choice, Socrates.
tgt_text.10813: Our argument however appears as if it would not allow both these to take place :
tgt_text.10814: though (for we must venture on every thing), what if we should determine to lay aside all shame ?
tgt_text.10818: By taking upon ourselves to declare what it is to know.
tgt_text.10820: But why would this be shameless ?
tgt_text.10823: You do not seem to consider that the whole of our discussion from the beginning has been an investigation respecting science, as if we did not know what it is.
tgt_text.10827: Does it not, then, appear to be a shameless thing, to explain what it is to know, when we are ignorant of what science is ?
tgt_text.10828: But, Theætetus, our conversation has been all along full of defects.
tgt_text.10829: For we have over and over again used the expressions, We know, and We do not know, We have a scientific knowledge, and We have not a scientific knowledge, as if we both of us understood something about it, whereas we are still ignorant of what science is.
tgt_text.10830: But if you please, we will still at the present moment use the terms, to be ignorant, and to understand, as if we could properly use them, though we are destitute of science.
tgt_text.10832: But how will you converse, Socrates, if you abstain from the use of these expressions ?
tgt_text.10834: Not at all, while I am what I am.
tgt_text.10835: If however I were contentious, or if a person of that kind were now present, he would say that I must abstain from them, and . would strongly object to what I say.
tgt_text.10836: But as we are poor creatures, do you wish I should venture to say what it is to know ?
tgt_text.10837: For it appears to me that it would be worth while to do so.
tgt_text.10840: for you will be readily pardoned for not abstaining from these expressions.
tgt_text.10843: Have you heard, then, what they now say it is to know ?
tgt_text.10846: but at present I do not remember.
tgt_text.10848: They say, I believe, that it is to have science.
tgt_text.10852: Let us, then, change it a little, and say that it is to possess science.
tgt_text.10854: But in what will you say this differs from that ?
tgt_text.10856: but whether it seems to differ or not, listen and examine with me.
tgt_text.10858: I will, if I am able.
tgt_text.10860: To possess, therefore, does not appear to me to be the same as to have:
tgt_text.10861: for instance, if any one having bought a garment, and having it in his power, should not wear it, we should not say that he has it, but that he possesses it.
tgt_text.10865: See then whether it is possible thus to possess science without having it:
tgt_text.10866: just as if any one having caught some wild birds, as doves or any others, and having constructed a dove­ cote at home, should feed them ;
tgt_text.10867: we should probably say that in some respects he always has them, because he possesses them :
tgt_text.10872: But in another respect we should say that he has none of them, but that he has acquired a power over them, since he has brought them under his control, in an enclosure of his own, so as to take and have them when he pleases, by catching whichever he wishes, and again of letting them go:
tgt_text.10873: and this he is at liberty to do as often as he thinks fit.
tgt_text.10877: Socr. Again, therefore, as in a former part of our dis­ cussion we constructed I know not what kind of waxen fig­ ment in the soul, so now let us make in each soul a kind of aviary of all sorts of birds, some being in flocks, apart from others, and others few together, and others alone, flying amongst all the rest wherever it may chance.
tgt_text.10882: While we are children, we must say, that this recep­ tacle is empty, and instead of birds we must understand sciences;
tgt_text.10883: whatever science, then, one has become possessed of and shut up in this enclosure, one must say that he has learnt or discovered the thing of which this is the science, and that this is to know.
tgt_text.10886: iSocr. Again, therefore, when any one wishes to catch any one of these sciences, and, when he has taken it, to have it, and again to let it go, consider what words he requires, whether the same as before, when he possessed them, or different ones.
tgt_text.10887: But from what follows you will more clearly understand what I mean.
tgt_text.10888: Do you call arithmetic an art ?
tgt_text.10891: Suppose this to be a catching of the sciences of every even and odd number.
tgt_text.10895: By this art, then, I think, he has the sciences of numbers under his control, and, if he pleases, transfers them to others.
tgt_text.10899: And we say that he who transfers them teaches, and that he who receives them learns, but that having them, by possessing them in that aviary, he knows them.
tgt_text.10902: Socr. Attend now to what follows.
tgt_text.10903: Does not he who is a perfect arithmetician know all numbers ?
tgt_text.10904: for the sciences of all numbers are in his soul.
tgt_text.10908: Does not then such a- person sometimes calculate either something within himself, or something else that is external, that is capable of being calculated.
tgt_text.10912: But to calculate we shall say is nothing else than to examine what is the quantity of any number.
